hypothesis that can be selected using the `alternative` parameter.

- `two-sided`: The null hypothesis is that the two distributions are
  identical, F(x)=G(x) for all x; the alternative is that they are not
  identical.

- `less`: The null hypothesis is that F(x) >= G(x) for all x; the
  alternative is that F(x) < G(x) for at least one x.

- `greater`: The null hypothesis is that F(x) <= G(x) for all x; the
  alternative is that F(x) > G(x) for at least one x.

Note that the alternative hypotheses describe the *CDFs* of the
underlying distributions, not the observed values. For example,
suppose x1 ~ F and x2 ~ G. If F(x) > G(x) for all x, the values in
x1 tend to be less than those in x2.


Examples
--------
Suppose we wish to test the null hypothesis that a sample is distributed
according to the standard normal.
We choose a confidence level of 95%; that is, we will reject the null
hypothesis in favor of the alternative if the p-value is less than 0.05.

When testing uniformly distributed data, we would expect the
null hypothesis to be rejected.

>>> from scipy import stats
>>> rng = np.random.default_rng()
>>> stats.kstest(stats.uniform.rvs(size=100, random_state=rng),
...              stats.norm.cdf)
KstestResult(statistic=0.5001899973268688, pvalue=1.1616392184763533e-23)

Indeed, the p-value is lower than our threshold of 0.05, so we reject the
null hypothesis in favor of the default "two-sided" alternative: the data
are *not* distributed according to the standard normal.

When testing random variates from the standard normal distribution, we
expect the data to be consistent with the null hypothesis most of the time.

>>> x = stats.norm.rvs(size=100, random_state=rng)
>>> stats.kstest(x, stats.norm.cdf)
KstestResult(statistic=0.05345882212970396, pvalue=0.9227159037744717)

As expected, the p-value of 0.92 is not below our threshold of 0.05, so
we cannot reject the null hypothesis.

Suppose, however, that the random variates are distributed according to
a normal distribution that is shifted toward greater values. In this case,
the cumulative density function (CDF) of the underlying distribution tends
to be *less* than the CDF of the standard normal. Therefore, we would
expect the null hypothesis to be rejected with ``alternative='less'``:

>>> x = stats.norm.rvs(size=100, loc=0.5, random_state=rng)
>>> stats.kstest(x, stats.norm.cdf, alternative='less')
KstestResult(statistic=0.17482387821055168, pvalue=0.001913921057766743)

and indeed, with p-value smaller than our threshold, we reject the null
hypothesis in favor of the alternative.

For convenience, the previous test can be performed using the name of the
distribution as the second argument.

>>> stats.kstest(x, "norm", alternative='less')
KstestResult(statistic=0.17482387821055168, pvalue=0.001913921057766743)

The examples above have all been one-sample tests identical to those
performed by `ks_1samp`. Note that `kstest` can also perform two-sample
tests identical to those performed by `ks_2samp`. For example, when two
samples are drawn from the same distribution, we expect the data to be
consistent with the null hypothesis most of the time.

>>> sample1 = stats.laplace.rvs(size=105, random_state=rng)
>>> sample2 = stats.laplace.rvs(size=95, random_state=rng)
>>> stats.kstest(sample1, sample2)
KstestResult(statistic=0.11779448621553884, pvalue=0.4494256912629795)

As expected, the p-value of 0.45 is not below our threshold of 0.05, so
we cannot reject the null hypothesis.
7908def kstest(rvs, cdf, args=(), N=20, alternative='two-sided', method='auto'):
7909 """
7910 Performs the (one-sample or two-sample) Kolmogorov-Smirnov test for
7911 goodness of fit.
7912
7913 The one-sample test compares the underlying distribution F(x) of a sample
7914 against a given distribution G(x). The two-sample test compares the
7915 underlying distributions of two independent samples. Both tests are valid
7916 only for continuous distributions.
7917
7918 Parameters
7919 ----------
7920 rvs : str, array_like, or callable
7921 If an array, it should be a 1-D array of observations of random
7922 variables.
7923 If a callable, it should be a function to generate random variables;
7924 it is required to have a keyword argument `size`.
7925 If a string, it should be the name of a distribution in `scipy.stats`,
7926 which will be used to generate random variables.
7927 cdf : str, array_like or callable
7928 If array_like, it should be a 1-D array of observations of random
7929 variables, and the two-sample test is performed
7930 (and rvs must be array_like).
7931 If a callable, that callable is used to calculate the cdf.
7932 If a string, it should be the name of a distribution in `scipy.stats`,
7933 which will be used as the cdf function.
7934 args : tuple, sequence, optional
7935 Distribution parameters, used if `rvs` or `cdf` are strings or
7936 callables.
7937 N : int, optional
7938 Sample size if `rvs` is string or callable. Default is 20.
7939 alternative : {'two-sided', 'less', 'greater'}, optional
7940 Defines the null and alternative hypotheses. Default is 'two-sided'.
7941 Please see explanations in the Notes below.
7942 method : {'auto', 'exact', 'approx', 'asymp'}, optional
7943 Defines the distribution used for calculating the p-value.
7944 The following options are available (default is 'auto'):
7945
7946 * 'auto' : selects one of the other options.
7947 * 'exact' : uses the exact distribution of test statistic.
7948 * 'approx' : approximates the two-sided probability with twice the
7949 one-sided probability
7950 * 'asymp': uses asymptotic distribution of test statistic
7951
7952 Returns
7953 -------
7954 statistic : float
7955 KS test statistic, either D, D+ or D-.
7956 pvalue : float
7957 One-tailed or two-tailed p-value.
7958
7959 See Also
7960 --------
7961 ks_2samp
7962
7963 Notes
7964 -----
7965 There are three options for the null and corresponding alternative
7966 hypothesis that can be selected using the `alternative` parameter.
7967
7968 - `two-sided`: The null hypothesis is that the two distributions are
7969 identical, F(x)=G(x) for all x; the alternative is that they are not
7970 identical.
7971
7972 - `less`: The null hypothesis is that F(x) >= G(x) for all x; the
7973 alternative is that F(x) < G(x) for at least one x.
7974
7975 - `greater`: The null hypothesis is that F(x) <= G(x) for all x; the
7976 alternative is that F(x) > G(x) for at least one x.
7977
7978 Note that the alternative hypotheses describe the *CDFs* of the
7979 underlying distributions, not the observed values. For example,
7980 suppose x1 ~ F and x2 ~ G. If F(x) > G(x) for all x, the values in
7981 x1 tend to be less than those in x2.
7982
7983
7984 Examples
7985 --------
7986 Suppose we wish to test the null hypothesis that a sample is distributed
7987 according to the standard normal.
7988 We choose a confidence level of 95%; that is, we will reject the null
7989 hypothesis in favor of the alternative if the p-value is less than 0.05.
7990
7991 When testing uniformly distributed data, we would expect the
7992 null hypothesis to be rejected.
7993
7994 >>> from scipy import stats
7995 >>> rng = np.random.default_rng()
7996 >>> stats.kstest(stats.uniform.rvs(size=100, random_state=rng),
7997 ... stats.norm.cdf)
7998 KstestResult(statistic=0.5001899973268688, pvalue=1.1616392184763533e-23)
7999
8000 Indeed, the p-value is lower than our threshold of 0.05, so we reject the
8001 null hypothesis in favor of the default "two-sided" alternative: the data
8002 are *not* distributed according to the standard normal.
8003
8004 When testing random variates from the standard normal distribution, we
8005 expect the data to be consistent with the null hypothesis most of the time.
8006
8007 >>> x = stats.norm.rvs(size=100, random_state=rng)
8008 >>> stats.kstest(x, stats.norm.cdf)
8009 KstestResult(statistic=0.05345882212970396, pvalue=0.9227159037744717)
8010
8011 As expected, the p-value of 0.92 is not below our threshold of 0.05, so
8012 we cannot reject the null hypothesis.
8013
8014 Suppose, however, that the random variates are distributed according to
8015 a normal distribution that is shifted toward greater values. In this case,
8016 the cumulative density function (CDF) of the underlying distribution tends
8017 to be *less* than the CDF of the standard normal. Therefore, we would
8018 expect the null hypothesis to be rejected with ``alternative='less'``:
8019
8020 >>> x = stats.norm.rvs(size=100, loc=0.5, random_state=rng)
8021 >>> stats.kstest(x, stats.norm.cdf, alternative='less')
8022 KstestResult(statistic=0.17482387821055168, pvalue=0.001913921057766743)
8023
8024 and indeed, with p-value smaller than our threshold, we reject the null
8025 hypothesis in favor of the alternative.
8026
8027 For convenience, the previous test can be performed using the name of the
8028 distribution as the second argument.
8029
8030 >>> stats.kstest(x, "norm", alternative='less')
8031 KstestResult(statistic=0.17482387821055168, pvalue=0.001913921057766743)
8032
8033 The examples above have all been one-sample tests identical to those
8034 performed by `ks_1samp`. Note that `kstest` can also perform two-sample
8035 tests identical to those performed by `ks_2samp`. For example, when two
8036 samples are drawn from the same distribution, we expect the data to be
8037 consistent with the null hypothesis most of the time.
8038
8039 >>> sample1 = stats.laplace.rvs(size=105, random_state=rng)
8040 >>> sample2 = stats.laplace.rvs(size=95, random_state=rng)
8041 >>> stats.kstest(sample1, sample2)
8042 KstestResult(statistic=0.11779448621553884, pvalue=0.4494256912629795)
8043
8044 As expected, the p-value of 0.45 is not below our threshold of 0.05, so
8045 we cannot reject the null hypothesis.
8046
8047 """
8048 # to not break compatibility with existing code
8049 if alternative == 'two_sided':
8050 alternative = 'two-sided'
8051 if alternative not in ['two-sided', 'greater', 'less']:
8052 raise ValueError("Unexpected alternative %s" % alternative)
8053 xvals, yvals, cdf = _parse_kstest_args(rvs, cdf, args, N)
8054 if cdf:
8055 return ks_1samp(xvals, cdf, args=args, alternative=alternative,
8056 method=method)
8057 return ks_2samp(xvals, yvals, alternative=alternative, method=method)
8058
8059

◆ kurtosis()

scipy.stats._stats_py.kurtosis (   a,
  axis = 0,
  fisher = True,
  bias = True,
  nan_policy = 'propagate' 
) 
Compute the kurtosis (Fisher or Pearson) of a dataset.

Kurtosis is the fourth central moment divided by the square of the
variance. If Fisher's definition is used, then 3.0 is subtracted from
the result to give 0.0 for a normal distribution.

If bias is False then the kurtosis is calculated using k statistics to
eliminate bias coming from biased moment estimators

Use `kurtosistest` to see if result is close enough to normal.

Parameters
----------
a : array
    Data for which the kurtosis is calculated.
axis : int or None, optional
    Axis along which the kurtosis is calculated. Default is 0.
    If None, compute over the whole array `a`.
fisher : bool, optional
    If True, Fisher's definition is used (normal ==> 0.0). If False,
    Pearson's definition is used (normal ==> 3.0).
bias : bool, optional
    If False, then the calculations are corrected for statistical bias.
nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
    Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 'propagate' returns nan,
    'raise' throws an error, 'omit' performs the calculations ignoring nan
    values. Default is 'propagate'.

Returns
-------
kurtosis : array
    The kurtosis of values along an axis, returning NaN where all values
    are equal.

References
----------
.. [1] Zwillinger, D. and Kokoska, S. (2000). CRC Standard
   Probability and Statistics Tables and Formulae. Chapman & Hall: New
   York. 2000.

Examples
--------
In Fisher's definiton, the kurtosis of the normal distribution is zero.
In the following example, the kurtosis is close to zero, because it was
calculated from the dataset, not from the continuous distribution.

>>> from scipy.stats import norm, kurtosis
>>> data = norm.rvs(size=1000, random_state=3)
>>> kurtosis(data)
-0.06928694200380558

The distribution with a higher kurtosis has a heavier tail.
The zero valued kurtosis of the normal distribution in Fisher's definition
can serve as a reference point.

>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> import scipy.stats as stats
>>> from scipy.stats import kurtosis

>>> x = np.linspace(-5, 5, 100)
>>> ax = plt.subplot()
>>> distnames = ['laplace', 'norm', 'uniform']

>>> for distname in distnames:
...     if distname == 'uniform':
...         dist = getattr(stats, distname)(loc=-2, scale=4)
...     else:
...         dist = getattr(stats, distname)
...     data = dist.rvs(size=1000)
...     kur = kurtosis(data, fisher=True)
...     y = dist.pdf(x)
...     ax.plot(x, y, label="{}, {}".format(distname, round(kur, 3)))
...     ax.legend()

The Laplace distribution has a heavier tail than the normal distribution.
The uniform distribution (which has negative kurtosis) has the thinnest
tail.
1366def kurtosis(a, axis=0, fisher=True, bias=True, nan_policy='propagate'):
1367 """Compute the kurtosis (Fisher or Pearson) of a dataset.
1368
1369 Kurtosis is the fourth central moment divided by the square of the
1370 variance. If Fisher's definition is used, then 3.0 is subtracted from
1371 the result to give 0.0 for a normal distribution.
1372
1373 If bias is False then the kurtosis is calculated using k statistics to
1374 eliminate bias coming from biased moment estimators
1375
1376 Use `kurtosistest` to see if result is close enough to normal.
1377
1378 Parameters
1379 ----------
1380 a : array
1381 Data for which the kurtosis is calculated.
1382 axis : int or None, optional
1383 Axis along which the kurtosis is calculated. Default is 0.
1384 If None, compute over the whole array `a`.
1385 fisher : bool, optional
1386 If True, Fisher's definition is used (normal ==> 0.0). If False,
1387 Pearson's definition is used (normal ==> 3.0).
1388 bias : bool, optional
1389 If False, then the calculations are corrected for statistical bias.
1390 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
1391 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 'propagate' returns nan,
1392 'raise' throws an error, 'omit' performs the calculations ignoring nan
1393 values. Default is 'propagate'.
1394
1395 Returns
1396 -------
1397 kurtosis : array
1398 The kurtosis of values along an axis, returning NaN where all values
1399 are equal.
1400
1401 References
1402 ----------
1403 .. [1] Zwillinger, D. and Kokoska, S. (2000). CRC Standard
1404 Probability and Statistics Tables and Formulae. Chapman & Hall: New
1405 York. 2000.
1406
1407 Examples
1408 --------
1409 In Fisher's definiton, the kurtosis of the normal distribution is zero.
1410 In the following example, the kurtosis is close to zero, because it was
1411 calculated from the dataset, not from the continuous distribution.
1412
1413 >>> from scipy.stats import norm, kurtosis
1414 >>> data = norm.rvs(size=1000, random_state=3)
1415 >>> kurtosis(data)
1416 -0.06928694200380558
1417
1418 The distribution with a higher kurtosis has a heavier tail.
1419 The zero valued kurtosis of the normal distribution in Fisher's definition
1420 can serve as a reference point.
1421
1422 >>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
1423 >>> import scipy.stats as stats
1424 >>> from scipy.stats import kurtosis
1425
1426 >>> x = np.linspace(-5, 5, 100)
1427 >>> ax = plt.subplot()
1428 >>> distnames = ['laplace', 'norm', 'uniform']
1429
1430 >>> for distname in distnames:
1431 ... if distname == 'uniform':
1432 ... dist = getattr(stats, distname)(loc=-2, scale=4)
1433 ... else:
1434 ... dist = getattr(stats, distname)
1435 ... data = dist.rvs(size=1000)
1436 ... kur = kurtosis(data, fisher=True)
1437 ... y = dist.pdf(x)
1438 ... ax.plot(x, y, label="{}, {}".format(distname, round(kur, 3)))
1439 ... ax.legend()
1440
1441 The Laplace distribution has a heavier tail than the normal distribution.
1442 The uniform distribution (which has negative kurtosis) has the thinnest
1443 tail.
1444
1445 """
1446 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis)
1447
1448 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy)
1449
1450 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit':
1451 a = ma.masked_invalid(a)
1452 return mstats_basic.kurtosis(a, axis, fisher, bias)
1453
1454 n = a.shape[axis]
1455 mean = a.mean(axis, keepdims=True)
1456 m2 = _moment(a, 2, axis, mean=mean)
1457 m4 = _moment(a, 4, axis, mean=mean)
1458 with np.errstate(all='ignore'):
1459 zero = (m2 <= (np.finfo(m2.dtype).resolution * mean.squeeze(axis))**2)
1460 vals = np.where(zero, np.nan, m4 / m2**2.0)
1461
1462 if not bias:
1463 can_correct = ~zero & (n > 3)
1464 if can_correct.any():
1465 m2 = np.extract(can_correct, m2)
1466 m4 = np.extract(can_correct, m4)
1467 nval = 1.0/(n-2)/(n-3) * ((n**2-1.0)*m4/m2**2.0 - 3*(n-1)**2.0)
1468 np.place(vals, can_correct, nval + 3.0)
1469
1470 if vals.ndim == 0:
1471 vals = vals.item() # array scalar
1472
1473 return vals - 3 if fisher else vals
1474
1475

◆ kurtosistest()

scipy.stats._stats_py.kurtosistest (   a,
  axis = 0,
  nan_policy = 'propagate',
  alternative = 'two-sided' 
) 
Test whether a dataset has normal kurtosis.

This function tests the null hypothesis that the kurtosis
of the population from which the sample was drawn is that
of the normal distribution.

Parameters
----------
a : array
    Array of the sample data.
axis : int or None, optional
   Axis along which to compute test. Default is 0. If None,
   compute over the whole array `a`.
nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
    Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
    The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):

    * 'propagate': returns nan
    * 'raise': throws an error
    * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values

alternative : {'two-sided', 'less', 'greater'}, optional
    Defines the alternative hypothesis.
    The following options are available (default is 'two-sided'):

    * 'two-sided': the kurtosis of the distribution underlying the sample
      is different from that of the normal distribution
    * 'less': the kurtosis of the distribution underlying the sample
      is less than that of the normal distribution
    * 'greater': the kurtosis of the distribution underlying the sample
      is greater than that of the normal distribution

    .. versionadded:: 1.7.0

Returns
-------
statistic : float
    The computed z-score for this test.
pvalue : float
    The p-value for the hypothesis test.

Notes
-----
Valid only for n>20. This function uses the method described in [1]_.

References
----------
.. [1] see e.g. F. J. Anscombe, W. J. Glynn, "Distribution of the kurtosis
   statistic b2 for normal samples", Biometrika, vol. 70, pp. 227-234, 1983.

Examples
--------
>>> from scipy.stats import kurtosistest
>>> kurtosistest(list(range(20)))
KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.7058104152122062, pvalue=0.08804338332528348)
>>> kurtosistest(list(range(20)), alternative='less')
KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.7058104152122062, pvalue=0.04402169166264174)
>>> kurtosistest(list(range(20)), alternative='greater')
KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.7058104152122062, pvalue=0.9559783083373583)

>>> rng = np.random.default_rng()
>>> s = rng.normal(0, 1, 1000)
>>> kurtosistest(s)
KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.475047944490622, pvalue=0.14019965402996987)
1691def kurtosistest(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate', alternative='two-sided'):
1692 """Test whether a dataset has normal kurtosis.
1693
1694 This function tests the null hypothesis that the kurtosis
1695 of the population from which the sample was drawn is that
1696 of the normal distribution.
1697
1698 Parameters
1699 ----------
1700 a : array
1701 Array of the sample data.
1702 axis : int or None, optional
1703 Axis along which to compute test. Default is 0. If None,
1704 compute over the whole array `a`.
1705 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
1706 Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
1707 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):
1708
1709 * 'propagate': returns nan
1710 * 'raise': throws an error
1711 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values
1712
1713 alternative : {'two-sided', 'less', 'greater'}, optional
1714 Defines the alternative hypothesis.
1715 The following options are available (default is 'two-sided'):
1716
1717 * 'two-sided': the kurtosis of the distribution underlying the sample
1718 is different from that of the normal distribution
1719 * 'less': the kurtosis of the distribution underlying the sample
1720 is less than that of the normal distribution
1721 * 'greater': the kurtosis of the distribution underlying the sample
1722 is greater than that of the normal distribution
1723
1724 .. versionadded:: 1.7.0
1725
1726 Returns
1727 -------
1728 statistic : float
1729 The computed z-score for this test.
1730 pvalue : float
1731 The p-value for the hypothesis test.
1732
1733 Notes
1734 -----
1735 Valid only for n>20. This function uses the method described in [1]_.
1736
1737 References
1738 ----------
1739 .. [1] see e.g. F. J. Anscombe, W. J. Glynn, "Distribution of the kurtosis
1740 statistic b2 for normal samples", Biometrika, vol. 70, pp. 227-234, 1983.
1741
1742 Examples
1743 --------
1744 >>> from scipy.stats import kurtosistest
1745 >>> kurtosistest(list(range(20)))
1746 KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.7058104152122062, pvalue=0.08804338332528348)
1747 >>> kurtosistest(list(range(20)), alternative='less')
1748 KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.7058104152122062, pvalue=0.04402169166264174)
1749 >>> kurtosistest(list(range(20)), alternative='greater')
1750 KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.7058104152122062, pvalue=0.9559783083373583)
1751
1752 >>> rng = np.random.default_rng()
1753 >>> s = rng.normal(0, 1, 1000)
1754 >>> kurtosistest(s)
1755 KurtosistestResult(statistic=-1.475047944490622, pvalue=0.14019965402996987)
1756
1757 """
1758 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis)
1759
1760 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy)
1761
1762 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit':
1763 a = ma.masked_invalid(a)
1764 return mstats_basic.kurtosistest(a, axis, alternative)
1765
1766 n = a.shape[axis]
1767 if n < 5:
1768 raise ValueError(
1769 "kurtosistest requires at least 5 observations; %i observations"
1770 " were given." % int(n))
1771 if n < 20:
1772 warnings.warn("kurtosistest only valid for n>=20 ... continuing "
1773 "anyway, n=%i" % int(n))
1774 b2 = kurtosis(a, axis, fisher=False)
1775
1776 E = 3.0*(n-1) / (n+1)
1777 varb2 = 24.0*n*(n-2)*(n-3) / ((n+1)*(n+1.)*(n+3)*(n+5)) # [1]_ Eq. 1
1778 x = (b2-E) / np.sqrt(varb2) # [1]_ Eq. 4
1779 # [1]_ Eq. 2:
1780 sqrtbeta1 = 6.0*(n*n-5*n+2)/((n+7)*(n+9)) * np.sqrt((6.0*(n+3)*(n+5)) /
1781 (n*(n-2)*(n-3)))
1782 # [1]_ Eq. 3:
1783 A = 6.0 + 8.0/sqrtbeta1 * (2.0/sqrtbeta1 + np.sqrt(1+4.0/(sqrtbeta1**2)))
1784 term1 = 1 - 2/(9.0*A)
1785 denom = 1 + x*np.sqrt(2/(A-4.0))
1786 term2 = np.sign(denom) * np.where(denom == 0.0, np.nan,
1787 np.power((1-2.0/A)/np.abs(denom), 1/3.0))
1788 if np.any(denom == 0):
1789 msg = "Test statistic not defined in some cases due to division by " \
1790 "zero. Return nan in that case..."
1791 warnings.warn(msg, RuntimeWarning)
1792
1793 Z = (term1 - term2) / np.sqrt(2/(9.0*A)) # [1]_ Eq. 5
1794
1795 # zprob uses upper tail, so Z needs to be positive
1796 return KurtosistestResult(*_normtest_finish(Z, alternative))
1797
1798

◆ median_abs_deviation()

scipy.stats._stats_py.median_abs_deviation (   x,
  axis = 0,
  center = np.median,
  scale = 1.0,
  nan_policy = 'propagate' 
) 
Compute the median absolute deviation of the data along the given axis.

The median absolute deviation (MAD, [1]_) computes the median over the
absolute deviations from the median. It is a measure of dispersion
similar to the standard deviation but more robust to outliers [2]_.

The MAD of an empty array is ``np.nan``.

.. versionadded:: 1.5.0

Parameters
----------
x : array_like
    Input array or object that can be converted to an array.
axis : int or None, optional
    Axis along which the range is computed. Default is 0. If None, compute
    the MAD over the entire array.
center : callable, optional
    A function that will return the central value. The default is to use
    np.median. Any user defined function used will need to have the
    function signature ``func(arr, axis)``.
scale : scalar or str, optional
    The numerical value of scale will be divided out of the final
    result. The default is 1.0. The string "normal" is also accepted,
    and results in `scale` being the inverse of the standard normal
    quantile function at 0.75, which is approximately 0.67449.
    Array-like scale is also allowed, as long as it broadcasts correctly
    to the output such that ``out / scale`` is a valid operation. The
    output dimensions depend on the input array, `x`, and the `axis`
    argument.
nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
    Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
    The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):

    * 'propagate': returns nan
    * 'raise': throws an error
    * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values

Returns
-------
mad : scalar or ndarray
    If ``axis=None``, a scalar is returned. If the input contains
    integers or floats of smaller precision than ``np.float64``, then the
    output data-type is ``np.float64``. Otherwise, the output data-type is
    the same as that of the input.

See Also
--------
numpy.std, numpy.var, numpy.median, scipy.stats.iqr, scipy.stats.tmean,
scipy.stats.tstd, scipy.stats.tvar

Notes
-----
The `center` argument only affects the calculation of the central value
around which the MAD is calculated. That is, passing in ``center=np.mean``
will calculate the MAD around the mean - it will not calculate the *mean*
absolute deviation.

The input array may contain `inf`, but if `center` returns `inf`, the
corresponding MAD for that data will be `nan`.

References
----------
.. [1] "Median absolute deviation",
       https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median_absolute_deviation
.. [2] "Robust measures of scale",
       https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_measures_of_scale

Examples
--------
When comparing the behavior of `median_abs_deviation` with ``np.std``,
the latter is affected when we change a single value of an array to have an
outlier value while the MAD hardly changes:

>>> from scipy import stats
>>> x = stats.norm.rvs(size=100, scale=1, random_state=123456)
>>> x.std()
0.9973906394005013
>>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x)
0.82832610097857
>>> x[0] = 345.6
>>> x.std()
34.42304872314415
>>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x)
0.8323442311590675

Axis handling example:

>>> x = np.array([[10, 7, 4], [3, 2, 1]])
>>> x
array([[10,  7,  4],
       [ 3,  2,  1]])
>>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x)
array([3.5, 2.5, 1.5])
>>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x, axis=None)
2.0

Scale normal example:

>>> x = stats.norm.rvs(size=1000000, scale=2, random_state=123456)
>>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x)
1.3487398527041636
>>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x, scale='normal')
1.9996446978061115
3232 nan_policy='propagate'):
3233 r"""
3234 Compute the median absolute deviation of the data along the given axis.
3235
3236 The median absolute deviation (MAD, [1]_) computes the median over the
3237 absolute deviations from the median. It is a measure of dispersion
3238 similar to the standard deviation but more robust to outliers [2]_.
3239
3240 The MAD of an empty array is ``np.nan``.
3241
3242 .. versionadded:: 1.5.0
3243
3244 Parameters
3245 ----------
3246 x : array_like
3247 Input array or object that can be converted to an array.
3248 axis : int or None, optional
3249 Axis along which the range is computed. Default is 0. If None, compute
3250 the MAD over the entire array.
3251 center : callable, optional
3252 A function that will return the central value. The default is to use
3253 np.median. Any user defined function used will need to have the
3254 function signature ``func(arr, axis)``.
3255 scale : scalar or str, optional
3256 The numerical value of scale will be divided out of the final
3257 result. The default is 1.0. The string "normal" is also accepted,
3258 and results in `scale` being the inverse of the standard normal
3259 quantile function at 0.75, which is approximately 0.67449.
3260 Array-like scale is also allowed, as long as it broadcasts correctly
3261 to the output such that ``out / scale`` is a valid operation. The
3262 output dimensions depend on the input array, `x`, and the `axis`
3263 argument.
3264 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
3265 Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
3266 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):
3267
3268 * 'propagate': returns nan
3269 * 'raise': throws an error
3270 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values
3271
3272 Returns
3273 -------
3274 mad : scalar or ndarray
3275 If ``axis=None``, a scalar is returned. If the input contains
3276 integers or floats of smaller precision than ``np.float64``, then the
3277 output data-type is ``np.float64``. Otherwise, the output data-type is
3278 the same as that of the input.
3279
3280 See Also
3281 --------
3282 numpy.std, numpy.var, numpy.median, scipy.stats.iqr, scipy.stats.tmean,
3283 scipy.stats.tstd, scipy.stats.tvar
3284
3285 Notes
3286 -----
3287 The `center` argument only affects the calculation of the central value
3288 around which the MAD is calculated. That is, passing in ``center=np.mean``
3289 will calculate the MAD around the mean - it will not calculate the *mean*
3290 absolute deviation.
3291
3292 The input array may contain `inf`, but if `center` returns `inf`, the
3293 corresponding MAD for that data will be `nan`.
3294
3295 References
3296 ----------
3297 .. [1] "Median absolute deviation",
3298 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median_absolute_deviation
3299 .. [2] "Robust measures of scale",
3300 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_measures_of_scale
3301
3302 Examples
3303 --------
3304 When comparing the behavior of `median_abs_deviation` with ``np.std``,
3305 the latter is affected when we change a single value of an array to have an
3306 outlier value while the MAD hardly changes:
3307
3308 >>> from scipy import stats
3309 >>> x = stats.norm.rvs(size=100, scale=1, random_state=123456)
3310 >>> x.std()
3311 0.9973906394005013
3312 >>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x)
3313 0.82832610097857
3314 >>> x[0] = 345.6
3315 >>> x.std()
3316 34.42304872314415
3317 >>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x)
3318 0.8323442311590675
3319
3320 Axis handling example:
3321
3322 >>> x = np.array([[10, 7, 4], [3, 2, 1]])
3323 >>> x
3324 array([[10, 7, 4],
3325 [ 3, 2, 1]])
3326 >>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x)
3327 array([3.5, 2.5, 1.5])
3328 >>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x, axis=None)
3329 2.0
3330
3331 Scale normal example:
3332
3333 >>> x = stats.norm.rvs(size=1000000, scale=2, random_state=123456)
3334 >>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x)
3335 1.3487398527041636
3336 >>> stats.median_abs_deviation(x, scale='normal')
3337 1.9996446978061115
3338
3339 """
3340 if not callable(center):
3341 raise TypeError("The argument 'center' must be callable. The given "
3342 f"value {repr(center)} is not callable.")
3343
3344 # An error may be raised here, so fail-fast, before doing lengthy
3345 # computations, even though `scale` is not used until later
3346 if isinstance(scale, str):
3347 if scale.lower() == 'normal':
3348 scale = 0.6744897501960817 # special.ndtri(0.75)
3349 else:
3350 raise ValueError(f"{scale} is not a valid scale value.")
3351
3352 x = asarray(x)
3353
3354 # Consistent with `np.var` and `np.std`.
3355 if not x.size:
3356 if axis is None:
3357 return np.nan
3358 nan_shape = tuple(item for i, item in enumerate(x.shape) if i != axis)
3359 if nan_shape == ():
3360 # Return nan, not array(nan)
3361 return np.nan
3362 return np.full(nan_shape, np.nan)
3363
3364 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(x, nan_policy)
3365
3366 if contains_nan:
3367 if axis is None:
3368 mad = _mad_1d(x.ravel(), center, nan_policy)
3369 else:
3370 mad = np.apply_along_axis(_mad_1d, axis, x, center, nan_policy)
3371 else:
3372 if axis is None:
3373 med = center(x, axis=None)
3374 mad = np.median(np.abs(x - med))
3375 else:
3376 # Wrap the call to center() in expand_dims() so it acts like
3377 # keepdims=True was used.
3378 med = np.expand_dims(center(x, axis=axis), axis)
3379 mad = np.median(np.abs(x - med), axis=axis)
3380
3381 return mad / scale
3382
3383

◆ mode()

scipy.stats._stats_py.mode (   a,
  axis = 0,
  nan_policy = 'propagate',
  keepdims = None 
) 
Return an array of the modal (most common) value in the passed array.

If there is more than one such value, only one is returned.
The bin-count for the modal bins is also returned.

Parameters
----------
a : array_like
n-dimensional array of which to find mode(s).
axis : int or None, optional
Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over
the whole array `a`.
nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):

* 'propagate': treats nan as it would treat any other value
* 'raise': throws an error
* 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values
keepdims : bool, optional
If set to ``False``, the `axis` over which the statistic is taken
is consumed (eliminated from the output array) like other reduction
functions (e.g. `skew`, `kurtosis`). If set to ``True``, the `axis` is
retained with size one, and the result will broadcast correctly
against the input array. The default, ``None``, is undefined legacy
behavior retained for backward compatibility.

.. warning::
Unlike other reduction functions (e.g. `skew`, `kurtosis`), the
default behavior of `mode` usually retains the the axis it acts
along. In SciPy 1.11.0, this behavior will change: the default
value of `keepdims` will become ``False``, the `axis` over which
the statistic is taken will be eliminated, and the value ``None``
will no longer be accepted.
.. versionadded:: 1.9.0

Returns
-------
mode : ndarray
Array of modal values.
count : ndarray
Array of counts for each mode.

Notes
-----
The mode of object arrays is calculated using `collections.Counter`, which
treats NaNs with different binary representations as distinct.

.. deprecated:: 1.9.0
Support for non-numeric arrays has been deprecated as of SciPy 1.9.0
and will be removed in 1.11.0. `pandas.DataFrame.mode`_ can
be used instead.

.. _pandas.DataFrame.mode: https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.mode.html

The mode of arrays with other dtypes is calculated using `numpy.unique`.
In NumPy versions 1.21 and after, all NaNs - even those with different
binary representations - are treated as equivalent and counted as separate
instances of the same value.

Examples
--------
>>> a = np.array([[6, 8, 3, 0],
...               [3, 2, 1, 7],
...               [8, 1, 8, 4],
...               [5, 3, 0, 5],
...               [4, 7, 5, 9]])
>>> from scipy import stats
>>> stats.mode(a, keepdims=True)
ModeResult(mode=array([[3, 1, 0, 0]]), count=array([[1, 1, 1, 1]]))

To get mode of whole array, specify ``axis=None``:

>>> stats.mode(a, axis=None, keepdims=True)
ModeResult(mode=array([3]), count=array([3]))
>>> stats.mode(a, axis=None, keepdims=False)
ModeResult(mode=3, count=3)
542def mode(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate', keepdims=None):
543 r"""Return an array of the modal (most common) value in the passed array.
544
545 If there is more than one such value, only one is returned.
546 The bin-count for the modal bins is also returned.
547
548 Parameters
549 ----------
550 a : array_like
551 n-dimensional array of which to find mode(s).
552 axis : int or None, optional
553 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over
554 the whole array `a`.
555 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
556 Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
557 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):
558
559 * 'propagate': treats nan as it would treat any other value
560 * 'raise': throws an error
561 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values
562 keepdims : bool, optional
563 If set to ``False``, the `axis` over which the statistic is taken
564 is consumed (eliminated from the output array) like other reduction
565 functions (e.g. `skew`, `kurtosis`). If set to ``True``, the `axis` is
566 retained with size one, and the result will broadcast correctly
567 against the input array. The default, ``None``, is undefined legacy
568 behavior retained for backward compatibility.
569
570 .. warning::
571 Unlike other reduction functions (e.g. `skew`, `kurtosis`), the
572 default behavior of `mode` usually retains the the axis it acts
573 along. In SciPy 1.11.0, this behavior will change: the default
574 value of `keepdims` will become ``False``, the `axis` over which
575 the statistic is taken will be eliminated, and the value ``None``
576 will no longer be accepted.
577 .. versionadded:: 1.9.0
578
579 Returns
580 -------
581 mode : ndarray
582 Array of modal values.
583 count : ndarray
584 Array of counts for each mode.
585
586 Notes
587 -----
588 The mode of object arrays is calculated using `collections.Counter`, which
589 treats NaNs with different binary representations as distinct.
590
591 .. deprecated:: 1.9.0
592 Support for non-numeric arrays has been deprecated as of SciPy 1.9.0
593 and will be removed in 1.11.0. `pandas.DataFrame.mode`_ can
594 be used instead.
595
596 .. _pandas.DataFrame.mode: https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.mode.html
597
598 The mode of arrays with other dtypes is calculated using `numpy.unique`.
599 In NumPy versions 1.21 and after, all NaNs - even those with different
600 binary representations - are treated as equivalent and counted as separate
601 instances of the same value.
602
603 Examples
604 --------
605 >>> a = np.array([[6, 8, 3, 0],
606 ... [3, 2, 1, 7],
607 ... [8, 1, 8, 4],
608 ... [5, 3, 0, 5],
609 ... [4, 7, 5, 9]])
610 >>> from scipy import stats
611 >>> stats.mode(a, keepdims=True)
612 ModeResult(mode=array([[3, 1, 0, 0]]), count=array([[1, 1, 1, 1]]))
613
614 To get mode of whole array, specify ``axis=None``:
615
616 >>> stats.mode(a, axis=None, keepdims=True)
617 ModeResult(mode=array([3]), count=array([3]))
618 >>> stats.mode(a, axis=None, keepdims=False)
619 ModeResult(mode=3, count=3)
620
621 """ # noqa: E501
622
623 if keepdims is None:
624 message = ("Unlike other reduction functions (e.g. `skew`, "
625 "`kurtosis`), the default behavior of `mode` typically "
626 "preserves the axis it acts along. In SciPy 1.11.0, "
627 "this behavior will change: the default value of "
628 "`keepdims` will become False, the `axis` over which "
629 "the statistic is taken will be eliminated, and the value "
630 "None will no longer be accepted. "
631 "Set `keepdims` to True or False to avoid this warning.")
632 warnings.warn(message, FutureWarning, stacklevel=2)
633
634 a = np.asarray(a)
635 if a.size == 0:
636 if keepdims is None:
637 return ModeResult(np.array([]), np.array([]))
638 else:
639 # this is tricky to get right; let np.mean do it
640 out = np.mean(a, axis=axis, keepdims=keepdims)
641 return ModeResult(out, out.copy())
642
643 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis)
644
645 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy)
646
647 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit':
648 a = ma.masked_invalid(a)
649 return mstats_basic.mode(a, axis, _keepdims=keepdims)
650
651 if not np.issubdtype(a.dtype, np.number):
652 warnings.warn("Support for non-numeric arrays has been deprecated "
653 "as of SciPy 1.9.0 and will be removed in "
654 "1.11.0. `pandas.DataFrame.mode` can be used instead, "
655 "see https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.mode.html.", # noqa: E501
656 DeprecationWarning, stacklevel=2)
657
658 if a.dtype == object:
659 def _mode1D(a):
660 cntr = Counter(a)
661 mode = max(cntr, key=lambda x: cntr[x])
662 return mode, cntr[mode]
663 else:
664 def _mode1D(a):
665 vals, cnts = np.unique(a, return_counts=True)
666 return vals[cnts.argmax()], cnts.max()
667
668 # np.apply_along_axis will convert the _mode1D tuples to a numpy array,
669 # casting types in the process.
670 # This recreates the results without that issue
671 # View of a, rotated so the requested axis is last
672 a_view = np.moveaxis(a, axis, -1)
673
674 inds = np.ndindex(a_view.shape[:-1])
675 modes = np.empty(a_view.shape[:-1], dtype=a.dtype)
676 counts = np.empty(a_view.shape[:-1], dtype=np.int_)
677 for ind in inds:
678 modes[ind], counts[ind] = _mode1D(a_view[ind])
679
680 if keepdims is None or keepdims:
681 newshape = list(a.shape)
682 newshape[axis] = 1
683 return ModeResult(modes.reshape(newshape), counts.reshape(newshape))
684 else:
685 return ModeResult(modes[()], counts[()])
686
687

◆ moment()

scipy.stats._stats_py.moment (   a,
  moment = 1,
  axis = 0,
  nan_policy = 'propagate' 
) 
Calculate the nth moment about the mean for a sample.

A moment is a specific quantitative measure of the shape of a set of
points. It is often used to calculate coefficients of skewness and kurtosis
due to its close relationship with them.

Parameters
----------
a : array_like
Input array.
moment : int or array_like of ints, optional
Order of central moment that is returned. Default is 1.
axis : int or None, optional
Axis along which the central moment is computed. Default is 0.
If None, compute over the whole array `a`.
nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):

* 'propagate': returns nan
* 'raise': throws an error
* 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values

Returns
-------
n-th central moment : ndarray or float
The appropriate moment along the given axis or over all values if axis
is None. The denominator for the moment calculation is the number of
observations, no degrees of freedom correction is done.

See Also
--------
kurtosis, skew, describe

Notes
-----
The k-th central moment of a data sample is:

.. math::

m_k = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i = 1}^n (x_i - \bar{x})^k

Where n is the number of samples and x-bar is the mean. This function uses
exponentiation by squares [1]_ for efficiency.

Note that, if `a` is an empty array (``a.size == 0``), array `moment` with
one element (`moment.size == 1`) is treated the same as scalar `moment`
(``np.isscalar(moment)``). This might produce arrays of unexpected shape.

References
----------
.. [1] https://eli.thegreenplace.net/2009/03/21/efficient-integer-exponentiation-algorithms

Examples
--------
>>> from scipy.stats import moment
>>> moment([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], moment=1)
0.0
>>> moment([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], moment=2)
2.0
1107def moment(a, moment=1, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate'):
1108 r"""Calculate the nth moment about the mean for a sample.
1109
1110 A moment is a specific quantitative measure of the shape of a set of
1111 points. It is often used to calculate coefficients of skewness and kurtosis
1112 due to its close relationship with them.
1113
1114 Parameters
1115 ----------
1116 a : array_like
1117 Input array.
1118 moment : int or array_like of ints, optional
1119 Order of central moment that is returned. Default is 1.
1120 axis : int or None, optional
1121 Axis along which the central moment is computed. Default is 0.
1122 If None, compute over the whole array `a`.
1123 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
1124 Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
1125 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):
1126
1127 * 'propagate': returns nan
1128 * 'raise': throws an error
1129 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values
1130
1131 Returns
1132 -------
1133 n-th central moment : ndarray or float
1134 The appropriate moment along the given axis or over all values if axis
1135 is None. The denominator for the moment calculation is the number of
1136 observations, no degrees of freedom correction is done.
1137
1138 See Also
1139 --------
1140 kurtosis, skew, describe
1141
1142 Notes
1143 -----
1144 The k-th central moment of a data sample is:
1145
1146 .. math::
1147
1148 m_k = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i = 1}^n (x_i - \bar{x})^k
1149
1150 Where n is the number of samples and x-bar is the mean. This function uses
1151 exponentiation by squares [1]_ for efficiency.
1152
1153 Note that, if `a` is an empty array (``a.size == 0``), array `moment` with
1154 one element (`moment.size == 1`) is treated the same as scalar `moment`
1155 (``np.isscalar(moment)``). This might produce arrays of unexpected shape.
1156
1157 References
1158 ----------
1159 .. [1] https://eli.thegreenplace.net/2009/03/21/efficient-integer-exponentiation-algorithms
1160
1161 Examples
1162 --------
1163 >>> from scipy.stats import moment
1164 >>> moment([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], moment=1)
1165 0.0
1166 >>> moment([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], moment=2)
1167 2.0
1168
1169 """
1170 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis)
1171
1172 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy)
1173
1174 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit':
1175 a = ma.masked_invalid(a)
1176 return mstats_basic.moment(a, moment, axis)
1177
1178 # for array_like moment input, return a value for each.
1179 if not np.isscalar(moment):
1180 mean = a.mean(axis, keepdims=True)
1181 mmnt = [_moment(a, i, axis, mean=mean) for i in moment]
1182 return np.array(mmnt)
1183 else:
1184 return _moment(a, moment, axis)
1185
1186
1187# Moment with optional pre-computed mean, equal to a.mean(axis, keepdims=True)

◆ multiscale_graphcorr()

scipy.stats._stats_py.multiscale_graphcorr (   x,
  y,
  compute_distance = _euclidean_dist,
  reps = 1000,
  workers = 1,
  is_twosamp = False,
  random_state = None 
) 
Computes the Multiscale Graph Correlation (MGC) test statistic.

Specifically, for each point, MGC finds the :math:`k`-nearest neighbors for
one property (e.g. cloud density), and the :math:`l`-nearest neighbors for
the other property (e.g. grass wetness) [1]_. This pair :math:`(k, l)` is
called the "scale". A priori, however, it is not know which scales will be
most informative. So, MGC computes all distance pairs, and then efficiently
computes the distance correlations for all scales. The local correlations
illustrate which scales are relatively informative about the relationship.
The key, therefore, to successfully discover and decipher relationships
between disparate data modalities is to adaptively determine which scales
are the most informative, and the geometric implication for the most
informative scales. Doing so not only provides an estimate of whether the
modalities are related, but also provides insight into how the
determination was made. This is especially important in high-dimensional
data, where simple visualizations do not reveal relationships to the
unaided human eye. Characterizations of this implementation in particular
have been derived from and benchmarked within in [2]_.

Parameters
----------
x, y : ndarray
    If ``x`` and ``y`` have shapes ``(n, p)`` and ``(n, q)`` where `n` is
    the number of samples and `p` and `q` are the number of dimensions,
    then the MGC independence test will be run.  Alternatively, ``x`` and
    ``y`` can have shapes ``(n, n)`` if they are distance or similarity
    matrices, and ``compute_distance`` must be sent to ``None``. If ``x``
    and ``y`` have shapes ``(n, p)`` and ``(m, p)``, an unpaired
    two-sample MGC test will be run.
compute_distance : callable, optional
    A function that computes the distance or similarity among the samples
    within each data matrix. Set to ``None`` if ``x`` and ``y`` are
    already distance matrices. The default uses the euclidean norm metric.
    If you are calling a custom function, either create the distance
    matrix before-hand or create a function of the form
    ``compute_distance(x)`` where `x` is the data matrix for which
    pairwise distances are calculated.
reps : int, optional
    The number of replications used to estimate the null when using the
    permutation test. The default is ``1000``.
workers : int or map-like callable, optional
    If ``workers`` is an int the population is subdivided into ``workers``
    sections and evaluated in parallel (uses ``multiprocessing.Pool
    <multiprocessing>``). Supply ``-1`` to use all cores available to the
    Process. Alternatively supply a map-like callable, such as
    ``multiprocessing.Pool.map`` for evaluating the p-value in parallel.
    This evaluation is carried out as ``workers(func, iterable)``.
    Requires that `func` be pickleable. The default is ``1``.
is_twosamp : bool, optional
    If `True`, a two sample test will be run. If ``x`` and ``y`` have
    shapes ``(n, p)`` and ``(m, p)``, this optional will be overridden and
    set to ``True``. Set to ``True`` if ``x`` and ``y`` both have shapes
    ``(n, p)`` and a two sample test is desired. The default is ``False``.
    Note that this will not run if inputs are distance matrices.
random_state : {None, int, `numpy.random.Generator`,
                `numpy.random.RandomState`}, optional

    If `seed` is None (or `np.random`), the `numpy.random.RandomState`
    singleton is used.
    If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used,
    seeded with `seed`.
    If `seed` is already a ``Generator`` or ``RandomState`` instance then
    that instance is used.

Returns
-------
stat : float
    The sample MGC test statistic within `[-1, 1]`.
pvalue : float
    The p-value obtained via permutation.
mgc_dict : dict
    Contains additional useful additional returns containing the following
    keys:

        - mgc_map : ndarray
            A 2D representation of the latent geometry of the relationship.
            of the relationship.
        - opt_scale : (int, int)
            The estimated optimal scale as a `(x, y)` pair.
        - null_dist : list
            The null distribution derived from the permuted matrices

See Also
--------
pearsonr : Pearson correlation coefficient and p-value for testing
           non-correlation.
kendalltau : Calculates Kendall's tau.
spearmanr : Calculates a Spearman rank-order correlation coefficient.

Notes
-----
A description of the process of MGC and applications on neuroscience data
can be found in [1]_. It is performed using the following steps:

#. Two distance matrices :math:`D^X` and :math:`D^Y` are computed and
   modified to be mean zero columnwise. This results in two
   :math:`n \times n` distance matrices :math:`A` and :math:`B` (the
   centering and unbiased modification) [3]_.

#. For all values :math:`k` and :math:`l` from :math:`1, ..., n`,

   * The :math:`k`-nearest neighbor and :math:`l`-nearest neighbor graphs
     are calculated for each property. Here, :math:`G_k (i, j)` indicates
     the :math:`k`-smallest values of the :math:`i`-th row of :math:`A`
     and :math:`H_l (i, j)` indicates the :math:`l` smallested values of
     the :math:`i`-th row of :math:`B`

   * Let :math:`\circ` denotes the entry-wise matrix product, then local
     correlations are summed and normalized using the following statistic:

.. math::

    c^{kl} = \frac{\sum_{ij} A G_k B H_l}
                  {\sqrt{\sum_{ij} A^2 G_k \times \sum_{ij} B^2 H_l}}

#. The MGC test statistic is the smoothed optimal local correlation of
   :math:`\{ c^{kl} \}`. Denote the smoothing operation as :math:`R(\cdot)`
   (which essentially set all isolated large correlations) as 0 and
   connected large correlations the same as before, see [3]_.) MGC is,

.. math::

    MGC_n (x, y) = \max_{(k, l)} R \left(c^{kl} \left( x_n, y_n \right)
                                                \right)

The test statistic returns a value between :math:`(-1, 1)` since it is
normalized.

The p-value returned is calculated using a permutation test. This process
is completed by first randomly permuting :math:`y` to estimate the null
distribution and then calculating the probability of observing a test
statistic, under the null, at least as extreme as the observed test
statistic.

MGC requires at least 5 samples to run with reliable results. It can also
handle high-dimensional data sets.
In addition, by manipulating the input data matrices, the two-sample
testing problem can be reduced to the independence testing problem [4]_.
Given sample data :math:`U` and :math:`V` of sizes :math:`p \times n`
:math:`p \times m`, data matrix :math:`X` and :math:`Y` can be created as
follows:

.. math::

    X = [U | V] \in \mathcal{R}^{p \times (n + m)}
    Y = [0_{1 \times n} | 1_{1 \times m}] \in \mathcal{R}^{(n + m)}

Then, the MGC statistic can be calculated as normal. This methodology can
be extended to similar tests such as distance correlation [4]_.

.. versionadded:: 1.4.0

References
----------
.. [1] Vogelstein, J. T., Bridgeford, E. W., Wang, Q., Priebe, C. E.,
       Maggioni, M., & Shen, C. (2019). Discovering and deciphering
       relationships across disparate data modalities. ELife.
.. [2] Panda, S., Palaniappan, S., Xiong, J., Swaminathan, A.,
       Ramachandran, S., Bridgeford, E. W., ... Vogelstein, J. T. (2019).
       mgcpy: A Comprehensive High Dimensional Independence Testing Python
       Package. :arXiv:`1907.02088`
.. [3] Shen, C., Priebe, C.E., & Vogelstein, J. T. (2019). From distance
       correlation to multiscale graph correlation. Journal of the American
       Statistical Association.
.. [4] Shen, C. & Vogelstein, J. T. (2018). The Exact Equivalence of
       Distance and Kernel Methods for Hypothesis Testing.
       :arXiv:`1806.05514`

Examples
--------
>>> from scipy.stats import multiscale_graphcorr
>>> x = np.arange(100)
>>> y = x
>>> stat, pvalue, _ = multiscale_graphcorr(x, y, workers=-1)
>>> '%.1f, %.3f' % (stat, pvalue)
'1.0, 0.001'

Alternatively,

>>> x = np.arange(100)
>>> y = x
>>> mgc = multiscale_graphcorr(x, y)
>>> '%.1f, %.3f' % (mgc.stat, mgc.pvalue)
'1.0, 0.001'

To run an unpaired two-sample test,

>>> x = np.arange(100)
>>> y = np.arange(79)
>>> mgc = multiscale_graphcorr(x, y)
>>> '%.3f, %.2f' % (mgc.stat, mgc.pvalue)  # doctest: +SKIP
'0.033, 0.02'

or, if shape of the inputs are the same,

>>> x = np.arange(100)
>>> y = x
>>> mgc = multiscale_graphcorr(x, y, is_twosamp=True)
>>> '%.3f, %.1f' % (mgc.stat, mgc.pvalue)  # doctest: +SKIP
'-0.008, 1.0'
5492 workers=1, is_twosamp=False, random_state=None):
5493 r"""Computes the Multiscale Graph Correlation (MGC) test statistic.
5494
5495 Specifically, for each point, MGC finds the :math:`k`-nearest neighbors for
5496 one property (e.g. cloud density), and the :math:`l`-nearest neighbors for
5497 the other property (e.g. grass wetness) [1]_. This pair :math:`(k, l)` is
5498 called the "scale". A priori, however, it is not know which scales will be
5499 most informative. So, MGC computes all distance pairs, and then efficiently
5500 computes the distance correlations for all scales. The local correlations
5501 illustrate which scales are relatively informative about the relationship.
5502 The key, therefore, to successfully discover and decipher relationships
5503 between disparate data modalities is to adaptively determine which scales
5504 are the most informative, and the geometric implication for the most
5505 informative scales. Doing so not only provides an estimate of whether the
5506 modalities are related, but also provides insight into how the
5507 determination was made. This is especially important in high-dimensional
5508 data, where simple visualizations do not reveal relationships to the
5509 unaided human eye. Characterizations of this implementation in particular
5510 have been derived from and benchmarked within in [2]_.
5511
5512 Parameters
5513 ----------
5514 x, y : ndarray
5515 If ``x`` and ``y`` have shapes ``(n, p)`` and ``(n, q)`` where `n` is
5516 the number of samples and `p` and `q` are the number of dimensions,
5517 then the MGC independence test will be run. Alternatively, ``x`` and
5518 ``y`` can have shapes ``(n, n)`` if they are distance or similarity
5519 matrices, and ``compute_distance`` must be sent to ``None``. If ``x``
5520 and ``y`` have shapes ``(n, p)`` and ``(m, p)``, an unpaired
5521 two-sample MGC test will be run.
5522 compute_distance : callable, optional
5523 A function that computes the distance or similarity among the samples
5524 within each data matrix. Set to ``None`` if ``x`` and ``y`` are
5525 already distance matrices. The default uses the euclidean norm metric.
5526 If you are calling a custom function, either create the distance
5527 matrix before-hand or create a function of the form
5528 ``compute_distance(x)`` where `x` is the data matrix for which
5529 pairwise distances are calculated.
5530 reps : int, optional
5531 The number of replications used to estimate the null when using the
5532 permutation test. The default is ``1000``.
5533 workers : int or map-like callable, optional
5534 If ``workers`` is an int the population is subdivided into ``workers``
5535 sections and evaluated in parallel (uses ``multiprocessing.Pool
5536 <multiprocessing>``). Supply ``-1`` to use all cores available to the
5537 Process. Alternatively supply a map-like callable, such as
5538 ``multiprocessing.Pool.map`` for evaluating the p-value in parallel.
5539 This evaluation is carried out as ``workers(func, iterable)``.
5540 Requires that `func` be pickleable. The default is ``1``.
5541 is_twosamp : bool, optional
5542 If `True`, a two sample test will be run. If ``x`` and ``y`` have
5543 shapes ``(n, p)`` and ``(m, p)``, this optional will be overridden and
5544 set to ``True``. Set to ``True`` if ``x`` and ``y`` both have shapes
5545 ``(n, p)`` and a two sample test is desired. The default is ``False``.
5546 Note that this will not run if inputs are distance matrices.
5547 random_state : {None, int, `numpy.random.Generator`,
5548 `numpy.random.RandomState`}, optional
5549
5550 If `seed` is None (or `np.random`), the `numpy.random.RandomState`
5551 singleton is used.
5552 If `seed` is an int, a new ``RandomState`` instance is used,
5553 seeded with `seed`.
5554 If `seed` is already a ``Generator`` or ``RandomState`` instance then
5555 that instance is used.
5556
5557 Returns
5558 -------
5559 stat : float
5560 The sample MGC test statistic within `[-1, 1]`.
5561 pvalue : float
5562 The p-value obtained via permutation.
5563 mgc_dict : dict
5564 Contains additional useful additional returns containing the following
5565 keys:
5566
5567 - mgc_map : ndarray
5568 A 2D representation of the latent geometry of the relationship.
5569 of the relationship.
5570 - opt_scale : (int, int)
5571 The estimated optimal scale as a `(x, y)` pair.
5572 - null_dist : list
5573 The null distribution derived from the permuted matrices
5574
5575 See Also
5576 --------
5577 pearsonr : Pearson correlation coefficient and p-value for testing
5578 non-correlation.
5579 kendalltau : Calculates Kendall's tau.
5580 spearmanr : Calculates a Spearman rank-order correlation coefficient.
5581
5582 Notes
5583 -----
5584 A description of the process of MGC and applications on neuroscience data
5585 can be found in [1]_. It is performed using the following steps:
5586
5587 #. Two distance matrices :math:`D^X` and :math:`D^Y` are computed and
5588 modified to be mean zero columnwise. This results in two
5589 :math:`n \times n` distance matrices :math:`A` and :math:`B` (the
5590 centering and unbiased modification) [3]_.
5591
5592 #. For all values :math:`k` and :math:`l` from :math:`1, ..., n`,
5593
5594 * The :math:`k`-nearest neighbor and :math:`l`-nearest neighbor graphs
5595 are calculated for each property. Here, :math:`G_k (i, j)` indicates
5596 the :math:`k`-smallest values of the :math:`i`-th row of :math:`A`
5597 and :math:`H_l (i, j)` indicates the :math:`l` smallested values of
5598 the :math:`i`-th row of :math:`B`
5599
5600 * Let :math:`\circ` denotes the entry-wise matrix product, then local
5601 correlations are summed and normalized using the following statistic:
5602
5603 .. math::
5604
5605 c^{kl} = \frac{\sum_{ij} A G_k B H_l}
5606 {\sqrt{\sum_{ij} A^2 G_k \times \sum_{ij} B^2 H_l}}
5607
5608 #. The MGC test statistic is the smoothed optimal local correlation of
5609 :math:`\{ c^{kl} \}`. Denote the smoothing operation as :math:`R(\cdot)`
5610 (which essentially set all isolated large correlations) as 0 and
5611 connected large correlations the same as before, see [3]_.) MGC is,
5612
5613 .. math::
5614
5615 MGC_n (x, y) = \max_{(k, l)} R \left(c^{kl} \left( x_n, y_n \right)
5616 \right)
5617
5618 The test statistic returns a value between :math:`(-1, 1)` since it is
5619 normalized.
5620
5621 The p-value returned is calculated using a permutation test. This process
5622 is completed by first randomly permuting :math:`y` to estimate the null
5623 distribution and then calculating the probability of observing a test
5624 statistic, under the null, at least as extreme as the observed test
5625 statistic.
5626
5627 MGC requires at least 5 samples to run with reliable results. It can also
5628 handle high-dimensional data sets.
5629 In addition, by manipulating the input data matrices, the two-sample
5630 testing problem can be reduced to the independence testing problem [4]_.
5631 Given sample data :math:`U` and :math:`V` of sizes :math:`p \times n`
5632 :math:`p \times m`, data matrix :math:`X` and :math:`Y` can be created as
5633 follows:
5634
5635 .. math::
5636
5637 X = [U | V] \in \mathcal{R}^{p \times (n + m)}
5638 Y = [0_{1 \times n} | 1_{1 \times m}] \in \mathcal{R}^{(n + m)}
5639
5640 Then, the MGC statistic can be calculated as normal. This methodology can
5641 be extended to similar tests such as distance correlation [4]_.
5642
5643 .. versionadded:: 1.4.0
5644
5645 References
5646 ----------
5647 .. [1] Vogelstein, J. T., Bridgeford, E. W., Wang, Q., Priebe, C. E.,
5648 Maggioni, M., & Shen, C. (2019). Discovering and deciphering
5649 relationships across disparate data modalities. ELife.
5650 .. [2] Panda, S., Palaniappan, S., Xiong, J., Swaminathan, A.,
5651 Ramachandran, S., Bridgeford, E. W., ... Vogelstein, J. T. (2019).
5652 mgcpy: A Comprehensive High Dimensional Independence Testing Python
5653 Package. :arXiv:`1907.02088`
5654 .. [3] Shen, C., Priebe, C.E., & Vogelstein, J. T. (2019). From distance
5655 correlation to multiscale graph correlation. Journal of the American
5656 Statistical Association.
5657 .. [4] Shen, C. & Vogelstein, J. T. (2018). The Exact Equivalence of
5658 Distance and Kernel Methods for Hypothesis Testing.
5659 :arXiv:`1806.05514`
5660
5661 Examples
5662 --------
5663 >>> from scipy.stats import multiscale_graphcorr
5664 >>> x = np.arange(100)
5665 >>> y = x
5666 >>> stat, pvalue, _ = multiscale_graphcorr(x, y, workers=-1)
5667 >>> '%.1f, %.3f' % (stat, pvalue)
5668 '1.0, 0.001'
5669
5670 Alternatively,
5671
5672 >>> x = np.arange(100)
5673 >>> y = x
5674 >>> mgc = multiscale_graphcorr(x, y)
5675 >>> '%.1f, %.3f' % (mgc.stat, mgc.pvalue)
5676 '1.0, 0.001'
5677
5678 To run an unpaired two-sample test,
5679
5680 >>> x = np.arange(100)
5681 >>> y = np.arange(79)
5682 >>> mgc = multiscale_graphcorr(x, y)
5683 >>> '%.3f, %.2f' % (mgc.stat, mgc.pvalue) # doctest: +SKIP
5684 '0.033, 0.02'
5685
5686 or, if shape of the inputs are the same,
5687
5688 >>> x = np.arange(100)
5689 >>> y = x
5690 >>> mgc = multiscale_graphcorr(x, y, is_twosamp=True)
5691 >>> '%.3f, %.1f' % (mgc.stat, mgc.pvalue) # doctest: +SKIP
5692 '-0.008, 1.0'
5693
5694 """
5695 if not isinstance(x, np.ndarray) or not isinstance(y, np.ndarray):
5696 raise ValueError("x and y must be ndarrays")
5697
5698 # convert arrays of type (n,) to (n, 1)
5699 if x.ndim == 1:
5700 x = x[:, np.newaxis]
5701 elif x.ndim != 2:
5702 raise ValueError("Expected a 2-D array `x`, found shape "
5703 "{}".format(x.shape))
5704 if y.ndim == 1:
5705 y = y[:, np.newaxis]
5706 elif y.ndim != 2:
5707 raise ValueError("Expected a 2-D array `y`, found shape "
5708 "{}".format(y.shape))
5709
5710 nx, px = x.shape
5711 ny, py = y.shape
5712
5713 # check for NaNs
5714 _contains_nan(x, nan_policy='raise')
5715 _contains_nan(y, nan_policy='raise')
5716
5717 # check for positive or negative infinity and raise error
5718 if np.sum(np.isinf(x)) > 0 or np.sum(np.isinf(y)) > 0:
5719 raise ValueError("Inputs contain infinities")
5720
5721 if nx != ny:
5722 if px == py:
5723 # reshape x and y for two sample testing
5724 is_twosamp = True
5725 else:
5726 raise ValueError("Shape mismatch, x and y must have shape [n, p] "
5727 "and [n, q] or have shape [n, p] and [m, p].")
5728
5729 if nx < 5 or ny < 5:
5730 raise ValueError("MGC requires at least 5 samples to give reasonable "
5731 "results.")
5732
5733 # convert x and y to float
5734 x = x.astype(np.float64)
5735 y = y.astype(np.float64)
5736
5737 # check if compute_distance_matrix if a callable()
5738 if not callable(compute_distance) and compute_distance is not None:
5739 raise ValueError("Compute_distance must be a function.")
5740
5741 # check if number of reps exists, integer, or > 0 (if under 1000 raises
5742 # warning)
5743 if not isinstance(reps, int) or reps < 0:
5744 raise ValueError("Number of reps must be an integer greater than 0.")
5745 elif reps < 1000:
5746 msg = ("The number of replications is low (under 1000), and p-value "
5747 "calculations may be unreliable. Use the p-value result, with "
5748 "caution!")
5749 warnings.warn(msg, RuntimeWarning)
5750
5751 if is_twosamp:
5752 if compute_distance is None:
5753 raise ValueError("Cannot run if inputs are distance matrices")
5754 x, y = _two_sample_transform(x, y)
5755
5756 if compute_distance is not None:
5757 # compute distance matrices for x and y
5758 x = compute_distance(x)
5759 y = compute_distance(y)
5760
5761 # calculate MGC stat
5762 stat, stat_dict = _mgc_stat(x, y)
5763 stat_mgc_map = stat_dict["stat_mgc_map"]
5764 opt_scale = stat_dict["opt_scale"]
5765
5766 # calculate permutation MGC p-value
5767 pvalue, null_dist = _perm_test(x, y, stat, reps=reps, workers=workers,
5768 random_state=random_state)
5769
5770 # save all stats (other than stat/p-value) in dictionary
5771 mgc_dict = {"mgc_map": stat_mgc_map,
5772 "opt_scale": opt_scale,
5773 "null_dist": null_dist}
5774
5775 return MGCResult(stat, pvalue, mgc_dict)
5776
5777

◆ normaltest()

scipy.stats._stats_py.normaltest (   a,
  axis = 0,
  nan_policy = 'propagate' 
) 
Test whether a sample differs from a normal distribution.

This function tests the null hypothesis that a sample comes
from a normal distribution.  It is based on D'Agostino and
Pearson's [1]_, [2]_ test that combines skew and kurtosis to
produce an omnibus test of normality.

Parameters
----------
a : array_like
    The array containing the sample to be tested.
axis : int or None, optional
    Axis along which to compute test. Default is 0. If None,
    compute over the whole array `a`.
nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
    Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
    The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):

      * 'propagate': returns nan
      * 'raise': throws an error
      * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values

Returns
-------
statistic : float or array
    ``s^2 + k^2``, where ``s`` is the z-score returned by `skewtest` and
    ``k`` is the z-score returned by `kurtosistest`.
pvalue : float or array
   A 2-sided chi squared probability for the hypothesis test.

References
----------
.. [1] D'Agostino, R. B. (1971), "An omnibus test of normality for
       moderate and large sample size", Biometrika, 58, 341-348

.. [2] D'Agostino, R. and Pearson, E. S. (1973), "Tests for departure from
       normality", Biometrika, 60, 613-622

Examples
--------
>>> from scipy import stats
>>> rng = np.random.default_rng()
>>> pts = 1000
>>> a = rng.normal(0, 1, size=pts)
>>> b = rng.normal(2, 1, size=pts)
>>> x = np.concatenate((a, b))
>>> k2, p = stats.normaltest(x)
>>> alpha = 1e-3
>>> print("p = {:g}".format(p))
p = 8.4713e-19
>>> if p < alpha:  # null hypothesis: x comes from a normal distribution
...     print("The null hypothesis can be rejected")
... else:
...     print("The null hypothesis cannot be rejected")
The null hypothesis can be rejected
1802def normaltest(a, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate'):
1803 """Test whether a sample differs from a normal distribution.
1804
1805 This function tests the null hypothesis that a sample comes
1806 from a normal distribution. It is based on D'Agostino and
1807 Pearson's [1]_, [2]_ test that combines skew and kurtosis to
1808 produce an omnibus test of normality.
1809
1810 Parameters
1811 ----------
1812 a : array_like
1813 The array containing the sample to be tested.
1814 axis : int or None, optional
1815 Axis along which to compute test. Default is 0. If None,
1816 compute over the whole array `a`.
1817 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
1818 Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
1819 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):
1820
1821 * 'propagate': returns nan
1822 * 'raise': throws an error
1823 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values
1824
1825 Returns
1826 -------
1827 statistic : float or array
1828 ``s^2 + k^2``, where ``s`` is the z-score returned by `skewtest` and
1829 ``k`` is the z-score returned by `kurtosistest`.
1830 pvalue : float or array
1831 A 2-sided chi squared probability for the hypothesis test.
1832
1833 References
1834 ----------
1835 .. [1] D'Agostino, R. B. (1971), "An omnibus test of normality for
1836 moderate and large sample size", Biometrika, 58, 341-348
1837
1838 .. [2] D'Agostino, R. and Pearson, E. S. (1973), "Tests for departure from
1839 normality", Biometrika, 60, 613-622
1840
1841 Examples
1842 --------
1843 >>> from scipy import stats
1844 >>> rng = np.random.default_rng()
1845 >>> pts = 1000
1846 >>> a = rng.normal(0, 1, size=pts)
1847 >>> b = rng.normal(2, 1, size=pts)
1848 >>> x = np.concatenate((a, b))
1849 >>> k2, p = stats.normaltest(x)
1850 >>> alpha = 1e-3
1851 >>> print("p = {:g}".format(p))
1852 p = 8.4713e-19
1853 >>> if p < alpha: # null hypothesis: x comes from a normal distribution
1854 ... print("The null hypothesis can be rejected")
1855 ... else:
1856 ... print("The null hypothesis cannot be rejected")
1857 The null hypothesis can be rejected
1858
1859 """
1860 a, axis = _chk_asarray(a, axis)
1861
1862 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy)
1863
1864 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit':
1865 a = ma.masked_invalid(a)
1866 return mstats_basic.normaltest(a, axis)
1867
1868 s, _ = skewtest(a, axis)
1869 k, _ = kurtosistest(a, axis)
1870 k2 = s*s + k*k
1871
1872 return NormaltestResult(k2, distributions.chi2.sf(k2, 2))
1873
1874

◆ obrientransform()

scipy.stats._stats_py.obrientransform ( *  samples)

VARIABILITY FUNCTIONS #. 

Compute the O'Brien transform on input data (any number of arrays).

Used to test for homogeneity of variance prior to running one-way stats.
Each array in ``*samples`` is one level of a factor.
If `f_oneway` is run on the transformed data and found significant,
the variances are unequal.  From Maxwell and Delaney [1]_, p.112.

Parameters
----------
sample1, sample2, ... : array_like
    Any number of arrays.

Returns
-------
obrientransform : ndarray
    Transformed data for use in an ANOVA.  The first dimension
    of the result corresponds to the sequence of transformed
    arrays.  If the arrays given are all 1-D of the same length,
    the return value is a 2-D array; otherwise it is a 1-D array
    of type object, with each element being an ndarray.

References
----------
.. [1] S. E. Maxwell and H. D. Delaney, "Designing Experiments and
       Analyzing Data: A Model Comparison Perspective", Wadsworth, 1990.

Examples
--------
We'll test the following data sets for differences in their variance.

>>> x = [10, 11, 13, 9, 7, 12, 12, 9, 10]
>>> y = [13, 21, 5, 10, 8, 14, 10, 12, 7, 15]

Apply the O'Brien transform to the data.

>>> from scipy.stats import obrientransform
>>> tx, ty = obrientransform(x, y)

Use `scipy.stats.f_oneway` to apply a one-way ANOVA test to the
transformed data.

>>> from scipy.stats import f_oneway
>>> F, p = f_oneway(tx, ty)
>>> p
0.1314139477040335

If we require that ``p < 0.05`` for significance, we cannot conclude
that the variances are different.
2474def obrientransform(*samples):
2475 """Compute the O'Brien transform on input data (any number of arrays).
2476
2477 Used to test for homogeneity of variance prior to running one-way stats.
2478 Each array in ``*samples`` is one level of a factor.
2479 If `f_oneway` is run on the transformed data and found significant,
2480 the variances are unequal. From Maxwell and Delaney [1]_, p.112.
2481
2482 Parameters
2483 ----------
2484 sample1, sample2, ... : array_like
2485 Any number of arrays.
2486
2487 Returns
2488 -------
2489 obrientransform : ndarray
2490 Transformed data for use in an ANOVA. The first dimension
2491 of the result corresponds to the sequence of transformed
2492 arrays. If the arrays given are all 1-D of the same length,
2493 the return value is a 2-D array; otherwise it is a 1-D array
2494 of type object, with each element being an ndarray.
2495
2496 References
2497 ----------
2498 .. [1] S. E. Maxwell and H. D. Delaney, "Designing Experiments and
2499 Analyzing Data: A Model Comparison Perspective", Wadsworth, 1990.
2500
2501 Examples
2502 --------
2503 We'll test the following data sets for differences in their variance.
2504
2505 >>> x = [10, 11, 13, 9, 7, 12, 12, 9, 10]
2506 >>> y = [13, 21, 5, 10, 8, 14, 10, 12, 7, 15]
2507
2508 Apply the O'Brien transform to the data.
2509
2510 >>> from scipy.stats import obrientransform
2511 >>> tx, ty = obrientransform(x, y)
2512
2513 Use `scipy.stats.f_oneway` to apply a one-way ANOVA test to the
2514 transformed data.
2515
2516 >>> from scipy.stats import f_oneway
2517 >>> F, p = f_oneway(tx, ty)
2518 >>> p
2519 0.1314139477040335
2520
2521 If we require that ``p < 0.05`` for significance, we cannot conclude
2522 that the variances are different.
2523
2524 """
2525 TINY = np.sqrt(np.finfo(float).eps)
2526
2527 # `arrays` will hold the transformed arguments.
2528 arrays = []
2529 sLast = None
2530
2531 for sample in samples:
2532 a = np.asarray(sample)
2533 n = len(a)
2534 mu = np.mean(a)
2535 sq = (a - mu)**2
2536 sumsq = sq.sum()
2537
2538 # The O'Brien transform.
2539 t = ((n - 1.5) * n * sq - 0.5 * sumsq) / ((n - 1) * (n - 2))
2540
2541 # Check that the mean of the transformed data is equal to the
2542 # original variance.
2543 var = sumsq / (n - 1)
2544 if abs(var - np.mean(t)) > TINY:
2545 raise ValueError('Lack of convergence in obrientransform.')
2546
2547 arrays.append(t)
2548 sLast = a.shape
2549
2550 if sLast:
2551 for arr in arrays[:-1]:
2552 if sLast != arr.shape:
2553 return np.array(arrays, dtype=object)
2554 return np.array(arrays)
2555
2556

◆ pearsonr()

scipy.stats._stats_py.pearsonr (   x,
  y,
*  alternative = 'two-sided' 
) 
Pearson correlation coefficient and p-value for testing non-correlation.

The Pearson correlation coefficient [1]_ measures the linear relationship
between two datasets. Like other correlation
coefficients, this one varies between -1 and +1 with 0 implying no
correlation. Correlations of -1 or +1 imply an exact linear relationship.
Positive correlations imply that as x increases, so does y. Negative
correlations imply that as x increases, y decreases.

This function also performs a test of the null hypothesis that the
distributions underlying the samples are uncorrelated and normally
distributed. (See Kowalski [3]_
for a discussion of the effects of non-normality of the input on the
distribution of the correlation coefficient.)
The p-value roughly indicates the probability of an uncorrelated system
producing datasets that have a Pearson correlation at least as extreme
as the one computed from these datasets.

Parameters
----------
x : (N,) array_like
Input array.
y : (N,) array_like
Input array.
alternative : {'two-sided', 'greater', 'less'}, optional
Defines the alternative hypothesis. Default is 'two-sided'.
The following options are available:

* 'two-sided': the correlation is nonzero
* 'less': the correlation is negative (less than zero)
* 'greater':  the correlation is positive (greater than zero)

.. versionadded:: 1.9.0

Returns
-------
result : `~scipy.stats._result_classes.PearsonRResult`
An object with the following attributes:

statistic : float
Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient.
pvalue : float
The p-value associated with the chosen alternative.

The object has the following method:

confidence_interval(confidence_level=0.95)
This method computes the confidence interval of the correlation
coefficient `statistic` for the given confidence level.
The confidence interval is returned in a ``namedtuple`` with
fields `low` and `high`.  See the Notes for more details.

Warns
-----
`~scipy.stats.ConstantInputWarning`
Raised if an input is a constant array.  The correlation coefficient
is not defined in this case, so ``np.nan`` is returned.

`~scipy.stats.NearConstantInputWarning`
Raised if an input is "nearly" constant.  The array ``x`` is considered
nearly constant if ``norm(x - mean(x)) < 1e-13 * abs(mean(x))``.
Numerical errors in the calculation ``x - mean(x)`` in this case might
result in an inaccurate calculation of r.

See Also
--------
spearmanr : Spearman rank-order correlation coefficient.
kendalltau : Kendall's tau, a correlation measure for ordinal data.

Notes
-----
The correlation coefficient is calculated as follows:

.. math::

r = \frac{\sum (x - m_x) (y - m_y)}
{\sqrt{\sum (x - m_x)^2 \sum (y - m_y)^2}}

where :math:`m_x` is the mean of the vector x and :math:`m_y` is
the mean of the vector y.

Under the assumption that x and y are drawn from
independent normal distributions (so the population correlation coefficient
is 0), the probability density function of the sample correlation
coefficient r is ([1]_, [2]_):

.. math::
f(r) = \frac{{(1-r^2)}^{n/2-2}}{\mathrm{B}(\frac{1}{2},\frac{n}{2}-1)}

where n is the number of samples, and B is the beta function.  This
is sometimes referred to as the exact distribution of r.  This is
the distribution that is used in `pearsonr` to compute the p-value.
The distribution is a beta distribution on the interval [-1, 1],
with equal shape parameters a = b = n/2 - 1.  In terms of SciPy's
implementation of the beta distribution, the distribution of r is::

dist = scipy.stats.beta(n/2 - 1, n/2 - 1, loc=-1, scale=2)

The default p-value returned by `pearsonr` is a two-sided p-value. For a
given sample with correlation coefficient r, the p-value is
the probability that abs(r') of a random sample x' and y' drawn from
the population with zero correlation would be greater than or equal
to abs(r). In terms of the object ``dist`` shown above, the p-value
for a given r and length n can be computed as::

p = 2*dist.cdf(-abs(r))

When n is 2, the above continuous distribution is not well-defined.
One can interpret the limit of the beta distribution as the shape
parameters a and b approach a = b = 0 as a discrete distribution with
equal probability masses at r = 1 and r = -1.  More directly, one
can observe that, given the data x = [x1, x2] and y = [y1, y2], and
assuming x1 != x2 and y1 != y2, the only possible values for r are 1
and -1.  Because abs(r') for any sample x' and y' with length 2 will
be 1, the two-sided p-value for a sample of length 2 is always 1.

For backwards compatibility, the object that is returned also behaves
like a tuple of length two that holds the statistic and the p-value.

References
----------
.. [1] "Pearson correlation coefficient", Wikipedia,
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearson_correlation_coefficient
