6509 Ttest_indResult(statistic=-1.9481646859513422, pvalue=0.05186270935842703)
6510 >>> stats.ttest_ind(rvs1, rvs4, equal_var=False)
6511 Ttest_indResult(statistic=-1.3146566100751664, pvalue=0.1913495266513811)
6512
6513 T-test with different means, variance, and n:
6514
6515 >>> rvs5 = stats.norm.rvs(loc=8, scale=20, size=100, random_state=rng)
6516 >>> stats.ttest_ind(rvs1, rvs5)
6517 Ttest_indResult(statistic=-2.8415950600298774, pvalue=0.0046418707568707885)
6518 >>> stats.ttest_ind(rvs1, rvs5, equal_var=False)
6519 Ttest_indResult(statistic=-1.8686598649188084, pvalue=0.06434714193919686)
6520
6521 When performing a permutation test, more permutations typically yields
6522 more accurate results. Use a ``np.random.Generator`` to ensure
6523 reproducibility:
6524
6525 >>> stats.ttest_ind(rvs1, rvs5, permutations=10000,
6526 ... random_state=rng)
6527 Ttest_indResult(statistic=-2.8415950600298774, pvalue=0.0052994700529947)
6528
6529 Take these two samples, one of which has an extreme tail.
6530
6531 >>> a = (56, 128.6, 12, 123.8, 64.34, 78, 763.3)
6532 >>> b = (1.1, 2.9, 4.2)
6533
6534 Use the `trim` keyword to perform a trimmed (Yuen) t-test. For example,
6535 using 20% trimming, ``trim=.2``, the test will reduce the impact of one
6536 (``np.floor(trim*len(a))``) element from each tail of sample `a`. It will
6537 have no effect on sample `b` because ``np.floor(trim*len(b))`` is 0.
6538
6539 >>> stats.ttest_ind(a, b, trim=.2)
6540 Ttest_indResult(statistic=3.4463884028073513,
6541 pvalue=0.01369338726499547)
6542 """
6543 if not (0 <= trim < .5):
6544 raise ValueError("Trimming percentage should be 0 <= `trim` < .5.")
6545
6546 a, b, axis = _chk2_asarray(a, b, axis)
6547
6548 # check both a and b
6549 cna, npa = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy)
6550 cnb, npb = _contains_nan(b, nan_policy)
6551 contains_nan = cna or cnb
6552 if npa == 'omit' or npb == 'omit':
6553 nan_policy = 'omit'
6554
6555 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit':
6556 if permutations or trim != 0:
6557 raise ValueError("nan-containing/masked inputs with "
6558 "nan_policy='omit' are currently not "
6559 "supported by permutation tests or "
6560 "trimmed tests.")
6561 a = ma.masked_invalid(a)
6562 b = ma.masked_invalid(b)
6563 return mstats_basic.ttest_ind(a, b, axis, equal_var, alternative)
6564
6565 if a.size == 0 or b.size == 0:
6566 return _ttest_nans(a, b, axis, Ttest_indResult)
6567
6568 if permutations is not None and permutations != 0:
6569 if trim != 0:
6570 raise ValueError("Permutations are currently not supported "
6571 "with trimming.")
6572 if permutations < 0 or (np.isfinite(permutations) and
6573 int(permutations) != permutations):
6574 raise ValueError("Permutations must be a non-negative integer.")
6575
6576 res = _permutation_ttest(a, b, permutations=permutations,
6577 axis=axis, equal_var=equal_var,
6578 nan_policy=nan_policy,
6579 random_state=random_state,
6580 alternative=alternative)
6581
6582 else:
6583 n1 = a.shape[axis]
6584 n2 = b.shape[axis]
6585
6586 if trim == 0:
6587 v1 = _var(a, axis, ddof=1)
6588 v2 = _var(b, axis, ddof=1)
6589 m1 = np.mean(a, axis)
6590 m2 = np.mean(b, axis)
6591 else:
6592 v1, m1, n1 = _ttest_trim_var_mean_len(a, trim, axis)
6593 v2, m2, n2 = _ttest_trim_var_mean_len(b, trim, axis)
6594
6595 if equal_var:
6596 df, denom = _equal_var_ttest_denom(v1, n1, v2, n2)
6597 else:
6598 df, denom = _unequal_var_ttest_denom(v1, n1, v2, n2)
6599 res = _ttest_ind_from_stats(m1, m2, denom, df, alternative)
6600 return Ttest_indResult(*res)
6601
6602

◆ ttest_ind_from_stats()

scipy.stats._stats_py.ttest_ind_from_stats (   mean1,
  std1,
  nobs1,
  mean2,
  std2,
  nobs2,
  equal_var = True,
  alternative = "two-sided" 
) 
T-test for means of two independent samples from descriptive statistics.

This is a test for the null hypothesis that two independent
samples have identical average (expected) values.

Parameters
----------
mean1 : array_like
    The mean(s) of sample 1.
std1 : array_like
    The corrected sample standard deviation of sample 1 (i.e. ``ddof=1``).
nobs1 : array_like
    The number(s) of observations of sample 1.
mean2 : array_like
    The mean(s) of sample 2.
std2 : array_like
    The corrected sample standard deviation of sample 2 (i.e. ``ddof=1``).
nobs2 : array_like
    The number(s) of observations of sample 2.
equal_var : bool, optional
    If True (default), perform a standard independent 2 sample test
    that assumes equal population variances [1]_.
    If False, perform Welch's t-test, which does not assume equal
    population variance [2]_.
alternative : {'two-sided', 'less', 'greater'}, optional
    Defines the alternative hypothesis.
    The following options are available (default is 'two-sided'):

    * 'two-sided': the means of the distributions are unequal.
    * 'less': the mean of the first distribution is less than the
      mean of the second distribution.
    * 'greater': the mean of the first distribution is greater than the
      mean of the second distribution.

    .. versionadded:: 1.6.0

Returns
-------
statistic : float or array
    The calculated t-statistics.
pvalue : float or array
    The two-tailed p-value.

See Also
--------
scipy.stats.ttest_ind

Notes
-----
The statistic is calculated as ``(mean1 - mean2)/se``, where ``se`` is the
standard error. Therefore, the statistic will be positive when `mean1` is
greater than `mean2` and negative when `mean1` is less than `mean2`.

References
----------
.. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-test#Independent_two-sample_t-test

.. [2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welch%27s_t-test

Examples
--------
Suppose we have the summary data for two samples, as follows (with the
Sample Variance being the corrected sample variance)::

                     Sample   Sample
               Size   Mean   Variance
    Sample 1    13    15.0     87.5
    Sample 2    11    12.0     39.0

Apply the t-test to this data (with the assumption that the population
variances are equal):

>>> from scipy.stats import ttest_ind_from_stats
>>> ttest_ind_from_stats(mean1=15.0, std1=np.sqrt(87.5), nobs1=13,
...                      mean2=12.0, std2=np.sqrt(39.0), nobs2=11)
Ttest_indResult(statistic=0.9051358093310269, pvalue=0.3751996797581487)

For comparison, here is the data from which those summary statistics
were taken.  With this data, we can compute the same result using
`scipy.stats.ttest_ind`:

>>> a = np.array([1, 3, 4, 6, 11, 13, 15, 19, 22, 24, 25, 26, 26])
>>> b = np.array([2, 4, 6, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15, 18, 19, 21])
>>> from scipy.stats import ttest_ind
>>> ttest_ind(a, b)
Ttest_indResult(statistic=0.905135809331027, pvalue=0.3751996797581486)

Suppose we instead have binary data and would like to apply a t-test to
compare the proportion of 1s in two independent groups::

                      Number of    Sample     Sample
                Size    ones        Mean     Variance
    Sample 1    150      30         0.2        0.161073
    Sample 2    200      45         0.225      0.175251

The sample mean :math:`\hat{p}` is the proportion of ones in the sample
and the variance for a binary observation is estimated by
:math:`\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})`.

>>> ttest_ind_from_stats(mean1=0.2, std1=np.sqrt(0.161073), nobs1=150,
...                      mean2=0.225, std2=np.sqrt(0.175251), nobs2=200)
Ttest_indResult(statistic=-0.5627187905196761, pvalue=0.5739887114209541)

For comparison, we could compute the t statistic and p-value using
arrays of 0s and 1s and `scipy.stat.ttest_ind`, as above.

>>> group1 = np.array([1]*30 + [0]*(150-30))
>>> group2 = np.array([1]*45 + [0]*(200-45))
>>> ttest_ind(group1, group2)
Ttest_indResult(statistic=-0.5627179589855622, pvalue=0.573989277115258)
6146 equal_var=True, alternative="two-sided"):
6147 r"""
6148 T-test for means of two independent samples from descriptive statistics.
6149
6150 This is a test for the null hypothesis that two independent
6151 samples have identical average (expected) values.
6152
6153 Parameters
6154 ----------
6155 mean1 : array_like
6156 The mean(s) of sample 1.
6157 std1 : array_like
6158 The corrected sample standard deviation of sample 1 (i.e. ``ddof=1``).
6159 nobs1 : array_like
6160 The number(s) of observations of sample 1.
6161 mean2 : array_like
6162 The mean(s) of sample 2.
6163 std2 : array_like
6164 The corrected sample standard deviation of sample 2 (i.e. ``ddof=1``).
6165 nobs2 : array_like
6166 The number(s) of observations of sample 2.
6167 equal_var : bool, optional
6168 If True (default), perform a standard independent 2 sample test
6169 that assumes equal population variances [1]_.
6170 If False, perform Welch's t-test, which does not assume equal
6171 population variance [2]_.
6172 alternative : {'two-sided', 'less', 'greater'}, optional
6173 Defines the alternative hypothesis.
6174 The following options are available (default is 'two-sided'):
6175
6176 * 'two-sided': the means of the distributions are unequal.
6177 * 'less': the mean of the first distribution is less than the
6178 mean of the second distribution.
6179 * 'greater': the mean of the first distribution is greater than the
6180 mean of the second distribution.
6181
6182 .. versionadded:: 1.6.0
6183
6184 Returns
6185 -------
6186 statistic : float or array
6187 The calculated t-statistics.
6188 pvalue : float or array
6189 The two-tailed p-value.
6190
6191 See Also
6192 --------
6193 scipy.stats.ttest_ind
6194
6195 Notes
6196 -----
6197 The statistic is calculated as ``(mean1 - mean2)/se``, where ``se`` is the
6198 standard error. Therefore, the statistic will be positive when `mean1` is
6199 greater than `mean2` and negative when `mean1` is less than `mean2`.
6200
6201 References
6202 ----------
6203 .. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-test#Independent_two-sample_t-test
6204
6205 .. [2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welch%27s_t-test
6206
6207 Examples
6208 --------
6209 Suppose we have the summary data for two samples, as follows (with the
6210 Sample Variance being the corrected sample variance)::
6211
6212 Sample Sample
6213 Size Mean Variance
6214 Sample 1 13 15.0 87.5
6215 Sample 2 11 12.0 39.0
6216
6217 Apply the t-test to this data (with the assumption that the population
6218 variances are equal):
6219
6220 >>> from scipy.stats import ttest_ind_from_stats
6221 >>> ttest_ind_from_stats(mean1=15.0, std1=np.sqrt(87.5), nobs1=13,
6222 ... mean2=12.0, std2=np.sqrt(39.0), nobs2=11)
6223 Ttest_indResult(statistic=0.9051358093310269, pvalue=0.3751996797581487)
6224
6225 For comparison, here is the data from which those summary statistics
6226 were taken. With this data, we can compute the same result using
6227 `scipy.stats.ttest_ind`:
6228
6229 >>> a = np.array([1, 3, 4, 6, 11, 13, 15, 19, 22, 24, 25, 26, 26])
6230 >>> b = np.array([2, 4, 6, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15, 18, 19, 21])
6231 >>> from scipy.stats import ttest_ind
6232 >>> ttest_ind(a, b)
6233 Ttest_indResult(statistic=0.905135809331027, pvalue=0.3751996797581486)
6234
6235 Suppose we instead have binary data and would like to apply a t-test to
6236 compare the proportion of 1s in two independent groups::
6237
6238 Number of Sample Sample
6239 Size ones Mean Variance
6240 Sample 1 150 30 0.2 0.161073
6241 Sample 2 200 45 0.225 0.175251
6242
6243 The sample mean :math:`\hat{p}` is the proportion of ones in the sample
6244 and the variance for a binary observation is estimated by
6245 :math:`\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})`.
6246
6247 >>> ttest_ind_from_stats(mean1=0.2, std1=np.sqrt(0.161073), nobs1=150,
6248 ... mean2=0.225, std2=np.sqrt(0.175251), nobs2=200)
6249 Ttest_indResult(statistic=-0.5627187905196761, pvalue=0.5739887114209541)
6250
6251 For comparison, we could compute the t statistic and p-value using
6252 arrays of 0s and 1s and `scipy.stat.ttest_ind`, as above.
6253
6254 >>> group1 = np.array([1]*30 + [0]*(150-30))
6255 >>> group2 = np.array([1]*45 + [0]*(200-45))
6256 >>> ttest_ind(group1, group2)
6257 Ttest_indResult(statistic=-0.5627179589855622, pvalue=0.573989277115258)
6258
6259 """
6260 mean1 = np.asarray(mean1)
6261 std1 = np.asarray(std1)
6262 mean2 = np.asarray(mean2)
6263 std2 = np.asarray(std2)
6264 if equal_var:
6265 df, denom = _equal_var_ttest_denom(std1**2, nobs1, std2**2, nobs2)
6266 else:
6267 df, denom = _unequal_var_ttest_denom(std1**2, nobs1,
6268 std2**2, nobs2)
6269
6270 res = _ttest_ind_from_stats(mean1, mean2, denom, df, alternative)
6271 return Ttest_indResult(*res)
6272
6273

◆ ttest_rel()

scipy.stats._stats_py.ttest_rel (   a,
  b,
  axis = 0,
  nan_policy = 'propagate',
  alternative = "two-sided" 
) 
Calculate the t-test on TWO RELATED samples of scores, a and b.

This is a test for the null hypothesis that two related or
repeated samples have identical average (expected) values.

Parameters
----------
a, b : array_like
    The arrays must have the same shape.
axis : int or None, optional
    Axis along which to compute test. If None, compute over the whole
    arrays, `a`, and `b`.
nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
    Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
    The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):

      * 'propagate': returns nan
      * 'raise': throws an error
      * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values
alternative : {'two-sided', 'less', 'greater'}, optional
    Defines the alternative hypothesis.
    The following options are available (default is 'two-sided'):

    * 'two-sided': the means of the distributions underlying the samples
      are unequal.
    * 'less': the mean of the distribution underlying the first sample
      is less than the mean of the distribution underlying the second
      sample.
    * 'greater': the mean of the distribution underlying the first
      sample is greater than the mean of the distribution underlying
      the second sample.

    .. versionadded:: 1.6.0

Returns
-------
statistic : float or array
    t-statistic.
pvalue : float or array
    The p-value.

Notes
-----
Examples for use are scores of the same set of student in
different exams, or repeated sampling from the same units. The
test measures whether the average score differs significantly
across samples (e.g. exams). If we observe a large p-value, for
example greater than 0.05 or 0.1 then we cannot reject the null
hypothesis of identical average scores. If the p-value is smaller
than the threshold, e.g. 1%, 5% or 10%, then we reject the null
hypothesis of equal averages. Small p-values are associated with
large t-statistics.

The statistic is calculated as ``np.mean(a - b)/se``, where ``se`` is the
standard error. Therefore, the statistic will be positive when the sample
mean of ``a - b`` is greater than zero and negative when the sample mean of
``a - b`` is less than zero.

References
----------
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-test#Dependent_t-test_for_paired_samples

Examples
--------
>>> from scipy import stats
>>> rng = np.random.default_rng()

>>> rvs1 = stats.norm.rvs(loc=5, scale=10, size=500, random_state=rng)
>>> rvs2 = (stats.norm.rvs(loc=5, scale=10, size=500, random_state=rng)
...         + stats.norm.rvs(scale=0.2, size=500, random_state=rng))
>>> stats.ttest_rel(rvs1, rvs2)
Ttest_relResult(statistic=-0.4549717054410304, pvalue=0.6493274702088672)
>>> rvs3 = (stats.norm.rvs(loc=8, scale=10, size=500, random_state=rng)
...         + stats.norm.rvs(scale=0.2, size=500, random_state=rng))
>>> stats.ttest_rel(rvs1, rvs3)
Ttest_relResult(statistic=-5.879467544540889, pvalue=7.540777129099917e-09)
6803def ttest_rel(a, b, axis=0, nan_policy='propagate', alternative="two-sided"):
6804 """Calculate the t-test on TWO RELATED samples of scores, a and b.
6805
6806 This is a test for the null hypothesis that two related or
6807 repeated samples have identical average (expected) values.
6808
6809 Parameters
6810 ----------
6811 a, b : array_like
6812 The arrays must have the same shape.
6813 axis : int or None, optional
6814 Axis along which to compute test. If None, compute over the whole
6815 arrays, `a`, and `b`.
6816 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
6817 Defines how to handle when input contains nan.
6818 The following options are available (default is 'propagate'):
6819
6820 * 'propagate': returns nan
6821 * 'raise': throws an error
6822 * 'omit': performs the calculations ignoring nan values
6823 alternative : {'two-sided', 'less', 'greater'}, optional
6824 Defines the alternative hypothesis.
6825 The following options are available (default is 'two-sided'):
6826
6827 * 'two-sided': the means of the distributions underlying the samples
6828 are unequal.
6829 * 'less': the mean of the distribution underlying the first sample
6830 is less than the mean of the distribution underlying the second
6831 sample.
6832 * 'greater': the mean of the distribution underlying the first
6833 sample is greater than the mean of the distribution underlying
6834 the second sample.
6835
6836 .. versionadded:: 1.6.0
6837
6838 Returns
6839 -------
6840 statistic : float or array
6841 t-statistic.
6842 pvalue : float or array
6843 The p-value.
6844
6845 Notes
6846 -----
6847 Examples for use are scores of the same set of student in
6848 different exams, or repeated sampling from the same units. The
6849 test measures whether the average score differs significantly
6850 across samples (e.g. exams). If we observe a large p-value, for
6851 example greater than 0.05 or 0.1 then we cannot reject the null
6852 hypothesis of identical average scores. If the p-value is smaller
6853 than the threshold, e.g. 1%, 5% or 10%, then we reject the null
6854 hypothesis of equal averages. Small p-values are associated with
6855 large t-statistics.
6856
6857 The statistic is calculated as ``np.mean(a - b)/se``, where ``se`` is the
6858 standard error. Therefore, the statistic will be positive when the sample
6859 mean of ``a - b`` is greater than zero and negative when the sample mean of
6860 ``a - b`` is less than zero.
6861
6862 References
6863 ----------
6864 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-test#Dependent_t-test_for_paired_samples
6865
6866 Examples
6867 --------
6868 >>> from scipy import stats
6869 >>> rng = np.random.default_rng()
6870
6871 >>> rvs1 = stats.norm.rvs(loc=5, scale=10, size=500, random_state=rng)
6872 >>> rvs2 = (stats.norm.rvs(loc=5, scale=10, size=500, random_state=rng)
6873 ... + stats.norm.rvs(scale=0.2, size=500, random_state=rng))
6874 >>> stats.ttest_rel(rvs1, rvs2)
6875 Ttest_relResult(statistic=-0.4549717054410304, pvalue=0.6493274702088672)
6876 >>> rvs3 = (stats.norm.rvs(loc=8, scale=10, size=500, random_state=rng)
6877 ... + stats.norm.rvs(scale=0.2, size=500, random_state=rng))
6878 >>> stats.ttest_rel(rvs1, rvs3)
6879 Ttest_relResult(statistic=-5.879467544540889, pvalue=7.540777129099917e-09)
6880
6881 """
6882 a, b, axis = _chk2_asarray(a, b, axis)
6883
6884 cna, npa = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy)
6885 cnb, npb = _contains_nan(b, nan_policy)
6886 contains_nan = cna or cnb
6887 if npa == 'omit' or npb == 'omit':
6888 nan_policy = 'omit'
6889
6890 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit':
6891 a = ma.masked_invalid(a)
6892 b = ma.masked_invalid(b)
6893 m = ma.mask_or(ma.getmask(a), ma.getmask(b))
6894 aa = ma.array(a, mask=m, copy=True)
6895 bb = ma.array(b, mask=m, copy=True)
6896 return mstats_basic.ttest_rel(aa, bb, axis, alternative)
6897
6898 na = _get_len(a, axis, "first argument")
6899 nb = _get_len(b, axis, "second argument")
6900 if na != nb:
6901 raise ValueError('unequal length arrays')
6902
6903 if na == 0:
6904 return _ttest_nans(a, b, axis, Ttest_relResult)
6905
6906 n = a.shape[axis]
6907 df = n - 1
6908
6909 d = (a - b).astype(np.float64)
6910 v = _var(d, axis, ddof=1)
6911 dm = np.mean(d, axis)
6912 denom = np.sqrt(v / n)
6913
6914 with np.errstate(divide='ignore', invalid='ignore'):
6915 t = np.divide(dm, denom)
6916 t, prob = _ttest_finish(df, t, alternative)
6917
6918 return Ttest_relResult(t, prob)
6919
6920
6921# Map from names to lambda_ values used in power_divergence().

◆ tvar()

scipy.stats._stats_py.tvar (   a,
  limits = None,
  inclusive = (True, True),
  axis = 0,
  ddof = 1 
) 
Compute the trimmed variance.

This function computes the sample variance of an array of values,
while ignoring values which are outside of given `limits`.

Parameters
----------
a : array_like
    Array of values.
limits : None or (lower limit, upper limit), optional
    Values in the input array less than the lower limit or greater than the
    upper limit will be ignored. When limits is None, then all values are
    used. Either of the limit values in the tuple can also be None
    representing a half-open interval.  The default value is None.
inclusive : (bool, bool), optional
    A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag).  These flags
    determine whether values exactly equal to the lower or upper limits
    are included.  The default value is (True, True).
axis : int or None, optional
    Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the
    whole array `a`.
ddof : int, optional
    Delta degrees of freedom.  Default is 1.

Returns
-------
tvar : float
    Trimmed variance.

Notes
-----
`tvar` computes the unbiased sample variance, i.e. it uses a correction
factor ``n / (n - 1)``.

Examples
--------
>>> from scipy import stats
>>> x = np.arange(20)
>>> stats.tvar(x)
35.0
>>> stats.tvar(x, (3,17))
20.0
783def tvar(a, limits=None, inclusive=(True, True), axis=0, ddof=1):
784 """Compute the trimmed variance.
785
786 This function computes the sample variance of an array of values,
787 while ignoring values which are outside of given `limits`.
788
789 Parameters
790 ----------
791 a : array_like
792 Array of values.
793 limits : None or (lower limit, upper limit), optional
794 Values in the input array less than the lower limit or greater than the
795 upper limit will be ignored. When limits is None, then all values are
796 used. Either of the limit values in the tuple can also be None
797 representing a half-open interval. The default value is None.
798 inclusive : (bool, bool), optional
799 A tuple consisting of the (lower flag, upper flag). These flags
800 determine whether values exactly equal to the lower or upper limits
801 are included. The default value is (True, True).
802 axis : int or None, optional
803 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over the
804 whole array `a`.
805 ddof : int, optional
806 Delta degrees of freedom. Default is 1.
807
808 Returns
809 -------
810 tvar : float
811 Trimmed variance.
812
813 Notes
814 -----
815 `tvar` computes the unbiased sample variance, i.e. it uses a correction
816 factor ``n / (n - 1)``.
817
818 Examples
819 --------
820 >>> from scipy import stats
821 >>> x = np.arange(20)
822 >>> stats.tvar(x)
823 35.0
824 >>> stats.tvar(x, (3,17))
825 20.0
826
827 """
828 a = asarray(a)
829 a = a.astype(float)
830 if limits is None:
831 return a.var(ddof=ddof, axis=axis)
832 am = _mask_to_limits(a, limits, inclusive)
833 amnan = am.filled(fill_value=np.nan)
834 return np.nanvar(amnan, ddof=ddof, axis=axis)
835
836

◆ wasserstein_distance()

scipy.stats._stats_py.wasserstein_distance (   u_values,
  v_values,
  u_weights = None,
  v_weights = None 
)

STATISTICAL DISTANCES #. 

    Compute the first Wasserstein distance between two 1D distributions.

    This distance is also known as the earth mover's distance, since it can be
    seen as the minimum amount of "work" required to transform :math:`u` into
    :math:`v`, where "work" is measured as the amount of distribution weight
    that must be moved, multiplied by the distance it has to be moved.

    .. versionadded:: 1.0.0

    Parameters
    ----------
    u_values, v_values : array_like
        Values observed in the (empirical) distribution.
    u_weights, v_weights : array_like, optional
        Weight for each value. If unspecified, each value is assigned the same
        weight.
        `u_weights` (resp. `v_weights`) must have the same length as
        `u_values` (resp. `v_values`). If the weight sum differs from 1, it
        must still be positive and finite so that the weights can be normalized
        to sum to 1.

    Returns
    -------
    distance : float
        The computed distance between the distributions.

    Notes
    -----
    The first Wasserstein distance between the distributions :math:`u` and
    :math:`v` is:

    .. math::

        l_1 (u, v) = \inf_{\pi \in \Gamma (u, v)} \int_{\mathbb{R} \times
        \mathbb{R}} |x-y| \mathrm{d} \pi (x, y)

    where :math:`\Gamma (u, v)` is the set of (probability) distributions on
    :math:`\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}` whose marginals are :math:`u` and
    :math:`v` on the first and second factors respectively.

    If :math:`U` and :math:`V` are the respective CDFs of :math:`u` and
    :math:`v`, this distance also equals to:

    .. math::

        l_1(u, v) = \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} |U-V|

    See [2]_ for a proof of the equivalence of both definitions.

    The input distributions can be empirical, therefore coming from samples
    whose values are effectively inputs of the function, or they can be seen as
    generalized functions, in which case they are weighted sums of Dirac delta
    functions located at the specified values.

    References
    ----------
    .. [1] "Wasserstein metric", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wasserstein_metric
    .. [2] Ramdas, Garcia, Cuturi "On Wasserstein Two Sample Testing and Related
           Families of Nonparametric Tests" (2015). :arXiv:`1509.02237`.

    Examples
    --------
    >>> from scipy.stats import wasserstein_distance
    >>> wasserstein_distance([0, 1, 3], [5, 6, 8])
    5.0
    >>> wasserstein_distance([0, 1], [0, 1], [3, 1], [2, 2])
    0.25
    >>> wasserstein_distance([3.4, 3.9, 7.5, 7.8], [4.5, 1.4],
    ...                      [1.4, 0.9, 3.1, 7.2], [3.2, 3.5])
    4.0781331438047861
8675def wasserstein_distance(u_values, v_values, u_weights=None, v_weights=None):
8676 r"""
8677 Compute the first Wasserstein distance between two 1D distributions.
8678
8679 This distance is also known as the earth mover's distance, since it can be
8680 seen as the minimum amount of "work" required to transform :math:`u` into
8681 :math:`v`, where "work" is measured as the amount of distribution weight
8682 that must be moved, multiplied by the distance it has to be moved.
8683
8684 .. versionadded:: 1.0.0
8685
8686 Parameters
8687 ----------
8688 u_values, v_values : array_like
8689 Values observed in the (empirical) distribution.
8690 u_weights, v_weights : array_like, optional
8691 Weight for each value. If unspecified, each value is assigned the same
8692 weight.
8693 `u_weights` (resp. `v_weights`) must have the same length as
8694 `u_values` (resp. `v_values`). If the weight sum differs from 1, it
8695 must still be positive and finite so that the weights can be normalized
8696 to sum to 1.
8697
8698 Returns
8699 -------
8700 distance : float
8701 The computed distance between the distributions.
8702
8703 Notes
8704 -----
8705 The first Wasserstein distance between the distributions :math:`u` and
8706 :math:`v` is:
8707
8708 .. math::
8709
8710 l_1 (u, v) = \inf_{\pi \in \Gamma (u, v)} \int_{\mathbb{R} \times
8711 \mathbb{R}} |x-y| \mathrm{d} \pi (x, y)
8712
8713 where :math:`\Gamma (u, v)` is the set of (probability) distributions on
8714 :math:`\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}` whose marginals are :math:`u` and
8715 :math:`v` on the first and second factors respectively.
8716
8717 If :math:`U` and :math:`V` are the respective CDFs of :math:`u` and
8718 :math:`v`, this distance also equals to:
8719
8720 .. math::
8721
8722 l_1(u, v) = \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} |U-V|
8723
8724 See [2]_ for a proof of the equivalence of both definitions.
8725
8726 The input distributions can be empirical, therefore coming from samples
8727 whose values are effectively inputs of the function, or they can be seen as
8728 generalized functions, in which case they are weighted sums of Dirac delta
8729 functions located at the specified values.
8730
8731 References
8732 ----------
8733 .. [1] "Wasserstein metric", https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wasserstein_metric
8734 .. [2] Ramdas, Garcia, Cuturi "On Wasserstein Two Sample Testing and Related
8735 Families of Nonparametric Tests" (2015). :arXiv:`1509.02237`.
8736
8737 Examples
8738 --------
8739 >>> from scipy.stats import wasserstein_distance
8740 >>> wasserstein_distance([0, 1, 3], [5, 6, 8])
8741 5.0
8742 >>> wasserstein_distance([0, 1], [0, 1], [3, 1], [2, 2])
8743 0.25
8744 >>> wasserstein_distance([3.4, 3.9, 7.5, 7.8], [4.5, 1.4],
8745 ... [1.4, 0.9, 3.1, 7.2], [3.2, 3.5])
8746 4.0781331438047861
8747
8748 """
8749 return _cdf_distance(1, u_values, v_values, u_weights, v_weights)
8750
8751

◆ weightedtau()

scipy.stats._stats_py.weightedtau (   x,
  y,
  rank = True,
  weigher = None,
  additive = True 
) 
Compute a weighted version of Kendall's :math:`\tau`.

The weighted :math:`\tau` is a weighted version of Kendall's
:math:`\tau` in which exchanges of high weight are more influential than
exchanges of low weight. The default parameters compute the additive
hyperbolic version of the index, :math:`\tau_\mathrm h`, which has
been shown to provide the best balance between important and
unimportant elements [1]_.

The weighting is defined by means of a rank array, which assigns a
nonnegative rank to each element (higher importance ranks being
associated with smaller values, e.g., 0 is the highest possible rank),
and a weigher function, which assigns a weight based on the rank to
each element. The weight of an exchange is then the sum or the product
of the weights of the ranks of the exchanged elements. The default
parameters compute :math:`\tau_\mathrm h`: an exchange between
elements with rank :math:`r` and :math:`s` (starting from zero) has
weight :math:`1/(r+1) + 1/(s+1)`.

Specifying a rank array is meaningful only if you have in mind an
external criterion of importance. If, as it usually happens, you do
not have in mind a specific rank, the weighted :math:`\tau` is
defined by averaging the values obtained using the decreasing
lexicographical rank by (`x`, `y`) and by (`y`, `x`). This is the
behavior with default parameters. Note that the convention used
here for ranking (lower values imply higher importance) is opposite
to that used by other SciPy statistical functions.

Parameters
----------
x, y : array_like
Arrays of scores, of the same shape. If arrays are not 1-D, they will
be flattened to 1-D.
rank : array_like of ints or bool, optional
A nonnegative rank assigned to each element. If it is None, the
decreasing lexicographical rank by (`x`, `y`) will be used: elements of
higher rank will be those with larger `x`-values, using `y`-values to
break ties (in particular, swapping `x` and `y` will give a different
result). If it is False, the element indices will be used
directly as ranks. The default is True, in which case this
function returns the average of the values obtained using the
decreasing lexicographical rank by (`x`, `y`) and by (`y`, `x`).
weigher : callable, optional
The weigher function. Must map nonnegative integers (zero
representing the most important element) to a nonnegative weight.
The default, None, provides hyperbolic weighing, that is,
rank :math:`r` is mapped to weight :math:`1/(r+1)`.
additive : bool, optional
If True, the weight of an exchange is computed by adding the
weights of the ranks of the exchanged elements; otherwise, the weights
are multiplied. The default is True.

Returns
-------
correlation : float
The weighted :math:`\tau` correlation index.
pvalue : float
Presently ``np.nan``, as the null statistics is unknown (even in the
additive hyperbolic case).

See Also
--------
kendalltau : Calculates Kendall's tau.
spearmanr : Calculates a Spearman rank-order correlation coefficient.
theilslopes : Computes the Theil-Sen estimator for a set of points (x, y).

Notes
-----
This function uses an :math:`O(n \log n)`, mergesort-based algorithm
[1]_ that is a weighted extension of Knight's algorithm for Kendall's
:math:`\tau` [2]_. It can compute Shieh's weighted :math:`\tau` [3]_
between rankings without ties (i.e., permutations) by setting
`additive` and `rank` to False, as the definition given in [1]_ is a
generalization of Shieh's.

NaNs are considered the smallest possible score.

.. versionadded:: 0.19.0

References
----------
.. [1] Sebastiano Vigna, "A weighted correlation index for rankings with
ties", Proceedings of the 24th international conference on World
Wide Web, pp. 1166-1176, ACM, 2015.
.. [2] W.R. Knight, "A Computer Method for Calculating Kendall's Tau with
Ungrouped Data", Journal of the American Statistical Association,
Vol. 61, No. 314, Part 1, pp. 436-439, 1966.
.. [3] Grace S. Shieh. "A weighted Kendall's tau statistic", Statistics &
Probability Letters, Vol. 39, No. 1, pp. 17-24, 1998.

Examples
--------
>>> from scipy import stats
>>> x = [12, 2, 1, 12, 2]
>>> y = [1, 4, 7, 1, 0]
>>> tau, p_value = stats.weightedtau(x, y)
>>> tau
-0.56694968153682723
>>> p_value
nan
>>> tau, p_value = stats.weightedtau(x, y, additive=False)
>>> tau
-0.62205716951801038

NaNs are considered the smallest possible score:

>>> x = [12, 2, 1, 12, 2]
>>> y = [1, 4, 7, 1, np.nan]
>>> tau, _ = stats.weightedtau(x, y)
>>> tau
-0.56694968153682723

This is exactly Kendall's tau:

>>> x = [12, 2, 1, 12, 2]
>>> y = [1, 4, 7, 1, 0]
>>> tau, _ = stats.weightedtau(x, y, weigher=lambda x: 1)
>>> tau
-0.47140452079103173

>>> x = [12, 2, 1, 12, 2]
>>> y = [1, 4, 7, 1, 0]
>>> stats.weightedtau(x, y, rank=None)
WeightedTauResult(correlation=-0.4157652301037516, pvalue=nan)
>>> stats.weightedtau(y, x, rank=None)
WeightedTauResult(correlation=-0.7181341329699028, pvalue=nan)
5231def weightedtau(x, y, rank=True, weigher=None, additive=True):
5232 r"""Compute a weighted version of Kendall's :math:`\tau`.
5233
5234 The weighted :math:`\tau` is a weighted version of Kendall's
5235 :math:`\tau` in which exchanges of high weight are more influential than
5236 exchanges of low weight. The default parameters compute the additive
5237 hyperbolic version of the index, :math:`\tau_\mathrm h`, which has
5238 been shown to provide the best balance between important and
5239 unimportant elements [1]_.
5240
5241 The weighting is defined by means of a rank array, which assigns a
5242 nonnegative rank to each element (higher importance ranks being
5243 associated with smaller values, e.g., 0 is the highest possible rank),
5244 and a weigher function, which assigns a weight based on the rank to
5245 each element. The weight of an exchange is then the sum or the product
5246 of the weights of the ranks of the exchanged elements. The default
5247 parameters compute :math:`\tau_\mathrm h`: an exchange between
5248 elements with rank :math:`r` and :math:`s` (starting from zero) has
5249 weight :math:`1/(r+1) + 1/(s+1)`.
5250
5251 Specifying a rank array is meaningful only if you have in mind an
5252 external criterion of importance. If, as it usually happens, you do
5253 not have in mind a specific rank, the weighted :math:`\tau` is
5254 defined by averaging the values obtained using the decreasing
5255 lexicographical rank by (`x`, `y`) and by (`y`, `x`). This is the
5256 behavior with default parameters. Note that the convention used
5257 here for ranking (lower values imply higher importance) is opposite
5258 to that used by other SciPy statistical functions.
5259
5260 Parameters
5261 ----------
5262 x, y : array_like
5263 Arrays of scores, of the same shape. If arrays are not 1-D, they will
5264 be flattened to 1-D.
5265 rank : array_like of ints or bool, optional
5266 A nonnegative rank assigned to each element. If it is None, the
5267 decreasing lexicographical rank by (`x`, `y`) will be used: elements of
5268 higher rank will be those with larger `x`-values, using `y`-values to
5269 break ties (in particular, swapping `x` and `y` will give a different
5270 result). If it is False, the element indices will be used
5271 directly as ranks. The default is True, in which case this
5272 function returns the average of the values obtained using the
5273 decreasing lexicographical rank by (`x`, `y`) and by (`y`, `x`).
5274 weigher : callable, optional
5275 The weigher function. Must map nonnegative integers (zero
5276 representing the most important element) to a nonnegative weight.
5277 The default, None, provides hyperbolic weighing, that is,
5278 rank :math:`r` is mapped to weight :math:`1/(r+1)`.
5279 additive : bool, optional
5280 If True, the weight of an exchange is computed by adding the
5281 weights of the ranks of the exchanged elements; otherwise, the weights
5282 are multiplied. The default is True.
5283
5284 Returns
5285 -------
5286 correlation : float
5287 The weighted :math:`\tau` correlation index.
5288 pvalue : float
5289 Presently ``np.nan``, as the null statistics is unknown (even in the
5290 additive hyperbolic case).
5291
5292 See Also
5293 --------
5294 kendalltau : Calculates Kendall's tau.
5295 spearmanr : Calculates a Spearman rank-order correlation coefficient.
5296 theilslopes : Computes the Theil-Sen estimator for a set of points (x, y).
5297
5298 Notes
5299 -----
5300 This function uses an :math:`O(n \log n)`, mergesort-based algorithm
5301 [1]_ that is a weighted extension of Knight's algorithm for Kendall's
5302 :math:`\tau` [2]_. It can compute Shieh's weighted :math:`\tau` [3]_
5303 between rankings without ties (i.e., permutations) by setting
5304 `additive` and `rank` to False, as the definition given in [1]_ is a
5305 generalization of Shieh's.
5306
5307 NaNs are considered the smallest possible score.
5308
5309 .. versionadded:: 0.19.0
5310
5311 References
5312 ----------
5313 .. [1] Sebastiano Vigna, "A weighted correlation index for rankings with
5314 ties", Proceedings of the 24th international conference on World
5315 Wide Web, pp. 1166-1176, ACM, 2015.
5316 .. [2] W.R. Knight, "A Computer Method for Calculating Kendall's Tau with
5317 Ungrouped Data", Journal of the American Statistical Association,
5318 Vol. 61, No. 314, Part 1, pp. 436-439, 1966.
5319 .. [3] Grace S. Shieh. "A weighted Kendall's tau statistic", Statistics &
5320 Probability Letters, Vol. 39, No. 1, pp. 17-24, 1998.
5321
5322 Examples
5323 --------
5324 >>> from scipy import stats
5325 >>> x = [12, 2, 1, 12, 2]
5326 >>> y = [1, 4, 7, 1, 0]
5327 >>> tau, p_value = stats.weightedtau(x, y)
5328 >>> tau
5329 -0.56694968153682723
5330 >>> p_value
5331 nan
5332 >>> tau, p_value = stats.weightedtau(x, y, additive=False)
5333 >>> tau
5334 -0.62205716951801038
5335
5336 NaNs are considered the smallest possible score:
5337
5338 >>> x = [12, 2, 1, 12, 2]
5339 >>> y = [1, 4, 7, 1, np.nan]
5340 >>> tau, _ = stats.weightedtau(x, y)
5341 >>> tau
5342 -0.56694968153682723
5343
5344 This is exactly Kendall's tau:
5345
5346 >>> x = [12, 2, 1, 12, 2]
5347 >>> y = [1, 4, 7, 1, 0]
5348 >>> tau, _ = stats.weightedtau(x, y, weigher=lambda x: 1)
5349 >>> tau
5350 -0.47140452079103173
5351
5352 >>> x = [12, 2, 1, 12, 2]
5353 >>> y = [1, 4, 7, 1, 0]
5354 >>> stats.weightedtau(x, y, rank=None)
5355 WeightedTauResult(correlation=-0.4157652301037516, pvalue=nan)
5356 >>> stats.weightedtau(y, x, rank=None)
5357 WeightedTauResult(correlation=-0.7181341329699028, pvalue=nan)
5358
5359 """
5360 x = np.asarray(x).ravel()
5361 y = np.asarray(y).ravel()
5362
5363 if x.size != y.size:
5364 raise ValueError("All inputs to `weightedtau` must be "
5365 "of the same size, "
5366 "found x-size %s and y-size %s" % (x.size, y.size))
5367 if not x.size:
5368 # Return NaN if arrays are empty
5369 return WeightedTauResult(np.nan, np.nan)
5370
5371 # If there are NaNs we apply _toint64()
5372 if np.isnan(np.sum(x)):
5373 x = _toint64(x)
5374 if np.isnan(np.sum(y)):
5375 y = _toint64(y)
5376
5377 # Reduce to ranks unsupported types
5378 if x.dtype != y.dtype:
5379 if x.dtype != np.int64:
5380 x = _toint64(x)
5381 if y.dtype != np.int64:
5382 y = _toint64(y)
5383 else:
5384 if x.dtype not in (np.int32, np.int64, np.float32, np.float64):
5385 x = _toint64(x)
5386 y = _toint64(y)
5387
5388 if rank is True:
5389 return WeightedTauResult((
5390 _weightedrankedtau(x, y, None, weigher, additive) +
5391 _weightedrankedtau(y, x, None, weigher, additive)
5392 ) / 2, np.nan)
5393
5394 if rank is False:
5395 rank = np.arange(x.size, dtype=np.intp)
5396 elif rank is not None:
5397 rank = np.asarray(rank).ravel()
5398 if rank.size != x.size:
5399 raise ValueError(
5400 "All inputs to `weightedtau` must be of the same size, "
5401 "found x-size %s and rank-size %s" % (x.size, rank.size)
5402 )
5403
5404 return WeightedTauResult(_weightedrankedtau(x, y, rank, weigher, additive),
5405 np.nan)
5406
5407
5408# FROM MGCPY: https://github.com/neurodata/mgcpy
5409
5410

◆ zmap()

scipy.stats._stats_py.zmap (   scores,
  compare,
  axis = 0,
  ddof = 0,
  nan_policy = 'propagate' 
) 
Calculate the relative z-scores.

Return an array of z-scores, i.e., scores that are standardized to
zero mean and unit variance, where mean and variance are calculated
from the comparison array.

Parameters
----------
scores : array_like
    The input for which z-scores are calculated.
compare : array_like
    The input from which the mean and standard deviation of the
    normalization are taken; assumed to have the same dimension as
    `scores`.
axis : int or None, optional
    Axis over which mean and variance of `compare` are calculated.
    Default is 0. If None, compute over the whole array `scores`.
ddof : int, optional
    Degrees of freedom correction in the calculation of the
    standard deviation. Default is 0.
nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
    Defines how to handle the occurrence of nans in `compare`.
    'propagate' returns nan, 'raise' raises an exception, 'omit'
    performs the calculations ignoring nan values. Default is
    'propagate'. Note that when the value is 'omit', nans in `scores`
    also propagate to the output, but they do not affect the z-scores
    computed for the non-nan values.

Returns
-------
zscore : array_like
    Z-scores, in the same shape as `scores`.

Notes
-----
This function preserves ndarray subclasses, and works also with
matrices and masked arrays (it uses `asanyarray` instead of
`asarray` for parameters).

Examples
--------
>>> from scipy.stats import zmap
>>> a = [0.5, 2.0, 2.5, 3]
>>> b = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
>>> zmap(a, b)
array([-1.06066017,  0.        ,  0.35355339,  0.70710678])
2824def zmap(scores, compare, axis=0, ddof=0, nan_policy='propagate'):
2825 """
2826 Calculate the relative z-scores.
2827
2828 Return an array of z-scores, i.e., scores that are standardized to
2829 zero mean and unit variance, where mean and variance are calculated
2830 from the comparison array.
2831
2832 Parameters
2833 ----------
2834 scores : array_like
2835 The input for which z-scores are calculated.
2836 compare : array_like
2837 The input from which the mean and standard deviation of the
2838 normalization are taken; assumed to have the same dimension as
2839 `scores`.
2840 axis : int or None, optional
2841 Axis over which mean and variance of `compare` are calculated.
2842 Default is 0. If None, compute over the whole array `scores`.
2843 ddof : int, optional
2844 Degrees of freedom correction in the calculation of the
2845 standard deviation. Default is 0.
2846 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
2847 Defines how to handle the occurrence of nans in `compare`.
2848 'propagate' returns nan, 'raise' raises an exception, 'omit'
2849 performs the calculations ignoring nan values. Default is
2850 'propagate'. Note that when the value is 'omit', nans in `scores`
2851 also propagate to the output, but they do not affect the z-scores
2852 computed for the non-nan values.
2853
2854 Returns
2855 -------
2856 zscore : array_like
2857 Z-scores, in the same shape as `scores`.
2858
2859 Notes
2860 -----
2861 This function preserves ndarray subclasses, and works also with
2862 matrices and masked arrays (it uses `asanyarray` instead of
2863 `asarray` for parameters).
2864
2865 Examples
2866 --------
2867 >>> from scipy.stats import zmap
2868 >>> a = [0.5, 2.0, 2.5, 3]
2869 >>> b = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
2870 >>> zmap(a, b)
2871 array([-1.06066017, 0. , 0.35355339, 0.70710678])
2872
2873 """
2874 a = np.asanyarray(compare)
2875
2876 if a.size == 0:
2877 return np.empty(a.shape)
2878
2879 contains_nan, nan_policy = _contains_nan(a, nan_policy)
2880
2881 if contains_nan and nan_policy == 'omit':
2882 if axis is None:
2883 mn = _quiet_nanmean(a.ravel())
2884 std = _quiet_nanstd(a.ravel(), ddof=ddof)
2885 isconst = _isconst(a.ravel())
2886 else:
2887 mn = np.apply_along_axis(_quiet_nanmean, axis, a)
2888 std = np.apply_along_axis(_quiet_nanstd, axis, a, ddof=ddof)
2889 isconst = np.apply_along_axis(_isconst, axis, a)
2890 else:
2891 mn = a.mean(axis=axis, keepdims=True)
2892 std = a.std(axis=axis, ddof=ddof, keepdims=True)
2893 if axis is None:
2894 isconst = (a.item(0) == a).all()
2895 else:
2896 isconst = (_first(a, axis) == a).all(axis=axis, keepdims=True)
2897
2898 # Set std deviations that are 0 to 1 to avoid division by 0.
2899 std[isconst] = 1.0
2900 z = (scores - mn) / std
2901 # Set the outputs associated with a constant input to nan.
2902 z[np.broadcast_to(isconst, z.shape)] = np.nan
2903 return z
2904
2905

◆ zscore()

scipy.stats._stats_py.zscore (   a,
  axis = 0,
  ddof = 0,
  nan_policy = 'propagate' 
) 
Compute the z score.

Compute the z score of each value in the sample, relative to the
sample mean and standard deviation.

Parameters
----------
a : array_like
    An array like object containing the sample data.
axis : int or None, optional
    Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over
    the whole array `a`.
ddof : int, optional
    Degrees of freedom correction in the calculation of the
    standard deviation. Default is 0.
nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
    Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 'propagate' returns nan,
    'raise' throws an error, 'omit' performs the calculations ignoring nan
    values. Default is 'propagate'.  Note that when the value is 'omit',
    nans in the input also propagate to the output, but they do not affect
    the z-scores computed for the non-nan values.

Returns
-------
zscore : array_like
    The z-scores, standardized by mean and standard deviation of
    input array `a`.

Notes
-----
This function preserves ndarray subclasses, and works also with
matrices and masked arrays (it uses `asanyarray` instead of
`asarray` for parameters).

Examples
--------
>>> a = np.array([ 0.7972,  0.0767,  0.4383,  0.7866,  0.8091,
...                0.1954,  0.6307,  0.6599,  0.1065,  0.0508])
>>> from scipy import stats
>>> stats.zscore(a)
array([ 1.1273, -1.247 , -0.0552,  1.0923,  1.1664, -0.8559,  0.5786,
        0.6748, -1.1488, -1.3324])

Computing along a specified axis, using n-1 degrees of freedom
(``ddof=1``) to calculate the standard deviation:

>>> b = np.array([[ 0.3148,  0.0478,  0.6243,  0.4608],
...               [ 0.7149,  0.0775,  0.6072,  0.9656],
...               [ 0.6341,  0.1403,  0.9759,  0.4064],
...               [ 0.5918,  0.6948,  0.904 ,  0.3721],
...               [ 0.0921,  0.2481,  0.1188,  0.1366]])
>>> stats.zscore(b, axis=1, ddof=1)
array([[-0.19264823, -1.28415119,  1.07259584,  0.40420358],
       [ 0.33048416, -1.37380874,  0.04251374,  1.00081084],
       [ 0.26796377, -1.12598418,  1.23283094, -0.37481053],
       [-0.22095197,  0.24468594,  1.19042819, -1.21416216],
       [-0.82780366,  1.4457416 , -0.43867764, -0.1792603 ]])

An example with `nan_policy='omit'`:

>>> x = np.array([[25.11, 30.10, np.nan, 32.02, 43.15],
...               [14.95, 16.06, 121.25, 94.35, 29.81]])
>>> stats.zscore(x, axis=1, nan_policy='omit')
array([[-1.13490897, -0.37830299,         nan, -0.08718406,  1.60039602],
       [-0.91611681, -0.89090508,  1.4983032 ,  0.88731639, -0.5785977 ]])
2665def zscore(a, axis=0, ddof=0, nan_policy='propagate'):
2666 """
2667 Compute the z score.
2668
2669 Compute the z score of each value in the sample, relative to the
2670 sample mean and standard deviation.
2671
2672 Parameters
2673 ----------
2674 a : array_like
2675 An array like object containing the sample data.
2676 axis : int or None, optional
2677 Axis along which to operate. Default is 0. If None, compute over
2678 the whole array `a`.
2679 ddof : int, optional
2680 Degrees of freedom correction in the calculation of the
2681 standard deviation. Default is 0.
2682 nan_policy : {'propagate', 'raise', 'omit'}, optional
2683 Defines how to handle when input contains nan. 'propagate' returns nan,
2684 'raise' throws an error, 'omit' performs the calculations ignoring nan
2685 values. Default is 'propagate'. Note that when the value is 'omit',
2686 nans in the input also propagate to the output, but they do not affect
2687 the z-scores computed for the non-nan values.
2688
2689 Returns
2690 -------
2691 zscore : array_like
2692 The z-scores, standardized by mean and standard deviation of
2693 input array `a`.
2694
2695 Notes
2696 -----
2697 This function preserves ndarray subclasses, and works also with
2698 matrices and masked arrays (it uses `asanyarray` instead of
2699 `asarray` for parameters).
2700
2701 Examples
2702 --------
2703 >>> a = np.array([ 0.7972, 0.0767, 0.4383, 0.7866, 0.8091,
2704 ... 0.1954, 0.6307, 0.6599, 0.1065, 0.0508])
2705 >>> from scipy import stats
2706 >>> stats.zscore(a)
2707 array([ 1.1273, -1.247 , -0.0552, 1.0923, 1.1664, -0.8559, 0.5786,
2708 0.6748, -1.1488, -1.3324])
2709
2710 Computing along a specified axis, using n-1 degrees of freedom
2711 (``ddof=1``) to calculate the standard deviation:
2712
2713 >>> b = np.array([[ 0.3148, 0.0478, 0.6243, 0.4608],
2714 ... [ 0.7149, 0.0775, 0.6072, 0.9656],
2715 ... [ 0.6341, 0.1403, 0.9759, 0.4064],
2716 ... [ 0.5918, 0.6948, 0.904 , 0.3721],
2717 ... [ 0.0921, 0.2481, 0.1188, 0.1366]])
2718 >>> stats.zscore(b, axis=1, ddof=1)
2719 array([[-0.19264823, -1.28415119, 1.07259584, 0.40420358],
2720 [ 0.33048416, -1.37380874, 0.04251374, 1.00081084],
2721 [ 0.26796377, -1.12598418, 1.23283094, -0.37481053],
2722 [-0.22095197, 0.24468594, 1.19042819, -1.21416216],
2723 [-0.82780366, 1.4457416 , -0.43867764, -0.1792603 ]])
2724
2725 An example with `nan_policy='omit'`:
2726
2727 >>> x = np.array([[25.11, 30.10, np.nan, 32.02, 43.15],
2728 ... [14.95, 16.06, 121.25, 94.35, 29.81]])
2729 >>> stats.zscore(x, axis=1, nan_policy='omit')
2730 array([[-1.13490897, -0.37830299, nan, -0.08718406, 1.60039602],
2731 [-0.91611681, -0.89090508, 1.4983032 , 0.88731639, -0.5785977 ]])
2732 """
2733 return zmap(a, a, axis=axis, ddof=ddof, nan_policy=nan_policy)
2734
2735
